  2. Âçï‰ΩçÂÖÉÂíåÈÄÜÂÖÉÊòØÂîØ‰∏ÄÁöÑ„ÄÇ

2. Èò∂

Áæ§ÁöÑÈò∂ÔºàorderÔºâÊòØÊåáÁæ§‰∏≠ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÊï∞Èáè„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÁæ§ GGG Êúâ nnn ‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÔºåÂàôÁß∞ GGG ÁöÑÈò∂‰∏∫ nnnÔºåËÆ∞‰∏∫ ‚à£G‚à£=n|G| = n‚à£G‚à£=n„ÄÇÈò∂ÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØÊúâÈôêÁöÑÊàñÊó†ÈôêÁöÑÔºåÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂèñÂÜ≥‰∫éÁæ§ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†Êï∞Èáè„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÊï¥Êï∞Âä†Ê≥ïÊûÑÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™Êó†ÈôêÈò∂ÁöÑÁæ§ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Êï¥Êï∞ÊòØÊó†ÈôêÁöÑÔºåËÄåÊØè‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•‰Ωú‰∏∫Áæ§ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇÂè¶‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÁü©Èòµ‰πòÊ≥ïÊûÑÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúâÈôêÈò∂ÁöÑÁæ§ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Áü©ÈòµÁöÑÊï∞ÈáèÊòØÊúâÈôêÁöÑ„ÄÇ

‰∏Ä‰∫õÁâπÊÆäÁöÑÁæ§

1. ‰∫§Êç¢Áæ§

‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ GGG Ë¢´Áß∞‰∏∫‰∫§Êç¢Áæ§ÔºàAbelian groupÔºâÔºåÂèàÁß∞‰∏∫ÈòøË¥ùÂ∞îÁæ§ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂØπ‰∫é GGG ‰∏≠‰ªªÊÑèÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥† aaa Âíå bbbÔºåÊúâ a‚ãÖb=b‚ãÖaa \cdot b=b \cdot aa‚ãÖb=b‚ãÖaÔºåÂç≥Áæ§ÁöÑËøêÁÆóÊª°Ë∂≥‰∫§Êç¢Âæã„ÄÇÊç¢Âè•ËØùËØ¥ÔºåGGG ‰∏≠‰ªªÊÑè‰∏§‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑ‰πòÁßØÁöÑÈ°∫Â∫è‰∏çÂΩ±ÂìçÁªìÊûú„ÄÇÈÄö‰øóÂú∞ËÆ≤ÔºåÈòøË¥ùÂ∞îÁæ§Â∞±ÊòØÂèØ‰ª•‚Äú‰∫§Êç¢‰ΩçÁΩÆ‚ÄùÁöÑÁæ§„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÊï¥Êï∞Âä†Ê≥ïÂíåÂÆûÊï∞‰πòÊ≥ïÈÉΩÊòØÈòøË¥ùÂ∞îÁæ§„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÊï¥Êï∞‰πòÊ≥ïÂíåÁΩÆÊç¢Áæ§ÈÉΩ‰∏çÊòØÈòøË¥ùÂ∞îÁæ§ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰πòÊ≥ï‰∏çÊª°Ë∂≥‰∫§Êç¢Âæã„ÄÇ

2. Â≠êÁæ§

ÁÆÄÂçïÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂ≠êÁæ§Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ÁöÑÊüê‰∏™Â≠êÈõÜÊª°Ë∂≥Áæ§ÁöÑÂõõ‰∏™Â±ûÊÄß„ÄÇ

‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ GGG ÁöÑÂ≠êÁæ§ÔºàsubgroupÔºâÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êª°Ë∂≥‰ª•‰∏ã‰∏â‰∏™Êù°‰ª∂ÁöÑ GGG ÁöÑÂ≠êÈõÜ HHHÔºö

  1. Â∞ÅÈó≠ÊÄß
  2. Âçï‰ΩçÂÖÉ
  3. ÁªìÂêàÊÄß
  4. ÈÄÜÂÖÉ

Áõ¥ËßÇ‰∏äÊù•ËØ¥Ôºå‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ GGG ÁöÑÂ≠êÁæ§ HHH ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âú® GGG ‰∏≠‚ÄúÂ∞ÅÈó≠‚ÄùÁöÑÂ≠êÈõÜÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†ÈÅµÂæ™Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑËøêÁÆóËßÑÂàôÔºåÂêåÊó∂ËøòÂåÖÂê´ GGG ÁöÑÂçï‰ΩçÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂíåÈÄÜÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇÊç¢Âè•ËØùËØ¥ÔºåHHH ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‚ÄúÂ∞èÁæ§‚ÄùÔºåÂÆÉÁªßÊâø‰∫Ü GGG ÁöÑËøêÁÆóËßÑÂàôÂíå‰∏Ä‰∫õÁâπÂæÅ„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÊï¥Êï∞Âä†Ê≥ïÊûÑÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ÔºåËÄåÊâÄÊúâÂÅ∂Êï∞ÁöÑÈõÜÂêà 0,2,‚àí2,4,‚àí4,...{0, 2, -2, 4, -4, ...}0,2,‚àí2,4,‚àí4,... ÊòØËøô‰∏™Áæ§ÁöÑÂ≠êÁæ§ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉÊª°Ë∂≥Â∞ÅÈó≠ÊÄß„ÄÅÂçï‰ΩçÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂíåÈÄÜÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÊù°‰ª∂„ÄÇÁ±ª‰ººÂú∞ÔºåÊ≠£ÊñπÂΩ¢ÁöÑÊóãËΩ¨Áæ§ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ÔºåËÄåÂÆÉÁöÑÊóãËΩ¨ËßíÂ∫¶ÊòØ 0‚àò0^\circ0‚àò, 90‚àò90^\circ90‚àò, 180‚àò180^\circ180‚àò Âíå 270‚àò270^\circ270‚àò ÁöÑÂ≠êÈõÜÊûÑÊàêÁöÑÈõÜÂêàÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠êÁæ§„ÄÇ

3. Âæ™ÁéØÁæ§

‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ GGG Ë¢´Áß∞‰∏∫Âæ™ÁéØÁæ§Ôºàcyclic groupÔºâÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂÆÉÂèØ‰ª•Áî±‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥† ggg ÁîüÊàêÔºåÂç≥ÂØπ‰∫é GGG ‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰ªªÊÑèÂÖÉÁ¥† xxxÔºåÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫Êàê x=gnx=g^nx=gn ÁöÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ nnn ÊòØÊï¥Êï∞„ÄÇÂú®ËøôÁßçÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Áß∞ ggg ‰∏∫ GGG ÁöÑÁîüÊàêÂÖÉÔºàgeneratorÔºâ„ÄÇ

Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏Ä‰∏™Áæ§ GGG ÊòØÊúâÈôêÁæ§ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÊòØÂæ™ÁéØÁæ§ÁöÑÂÖÖË¶ÅÊù°‰ª∂ÊòØ GGG ‰∏≠Â≠òÂú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥† gggÔºå‰ΩøÂæó ggg ÁöÑÈò∂Á≠â‰∫é GGG ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†‰∏™Êï∞ÔºåÂç≥ ‚à£G‚à£=n|G|=n‚à£G‚à£=nÔºå‰∏î gn=eg^n=egn=eÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ eee ÊòØ GGG ÁöÑÂçï‰ΩçÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇ

Â¶ÇÊûú GGG ÊòØÊó†ÈôêÁæ§ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÊòØÂæ™ÁéØÁæ§ÁöÑÂÖÖË¶ÅÊù°‰ª∂ÊòØ GGG ‰∏≠Â≠òÂú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥† gggÔºå‰ΩøÂæóÂØπ‰∫é‰ªªÊÑèÊï¥Êï∞ nnnÔºågng^ngn ÈÉΩÂú® GGG ‰∏≠Âá∫Áé∞ÔºåÂπ∂‰∏î gn‚â†eg^n \neq egnÓÄ†=e ÂØπ‰∫éÊâÄÊúâÈùûÈõ∂Êï¥Êï∞ nnn ÊàêÁ´ãÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ eee ÊòØ GGG ÁöÑÂçï‰ΩçÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇ

‰∏Ä‰∏™Âæ™ÁéØÁæ§ÁöÑÊÄßË¥®ÊØîËæÉÁÆÄÂçïÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÊØè‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÁîüÊàêÂÖÉË°®Á§∫ÔºåËÄå‰∏îÂØπ‰∫éÊúâÈôêÂæ™ÁéØÁæ§ÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†‰∏™Êï∞Á≠â‰∫éÁîüÊàêÂÖÉÁöÑÈò∂„ÄÇ

entry.title: CS100 Homework [3]
entry.content:
Problems:

  1. Chihiro Fujisaki and Caesar Cipher
  2. Chihiro Fujisaki and Keyworded Caesar Cipher
  3. Nagito Komaeda and lucky days
  4. Chiaki Nanami Wants to Play Games
  5. Gundham Tanaka and the Dark Devas of Destruction

CS100 Homework 3 (Spring 2023)

Deadline: 2023-03-15 (Wed) 23:59:59

Late submission will open for 24 hours after the deadline, with 50% point deduction.

If you get full marks in this assignment by no more than 40 submission attempts and also solve the challenge in problem 4, you can earn special OJ displays and a "1-case protection" that can be used in further assignments to cancel one testcase failure. See Piazza or OJ dashboard for more information.

Chihiro Fujisaki and Caesar Cipher

"If I don't do something, nothing's ever going to change."

Description:

Chihiro Fujisaki, the Ultimate Programmer, is developing a new kind of artificial intelligence called Alter Ego. Now he is training the artificial intelligence secretly in order to prevent Monokuma spotting it.

Fujisaki is training Alter Ego with Caesar cipher, an ancient encryption algorithm. With a fixed number as key, for example, 333, Caesar cipher replaces each letter in the plaintext a letter 333 positions down the alphabet. In this case, the message box becomes era, because going down 333 letters turns b into e and turns x, going through the alphabet, into a.

Fujisaki's messages contain uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and other characters like spaces and punctuations. He doesn't want to scramble his messages, so he keeps the cases and encrypts uppercase letters, lowercase letters and digits respectively (so that Z encodes to C and 9 to 2). All other characters, including spaces and punctuations, are not encoded.

Monokuma has discovered this secret, and has obtained the secret key. Please help Monokuma to decrypt Fujisaki's messages.

Input Format:

The input contains two lines:

The first line contains a number nnn, the key for Caesar cipher. n>0n>0n>0 shifts the message right (going down the alphabet), and n<0n<0n<0 shifts it left (going up the alphabet).

The second line contains a non-empty string ciphertext, the encoded text, ending with a line break character ('\n'). Only uppercase letters, lowercase letters, and digits have been encoded.

It is guaranteed that ‚à£n‚à£‚â§106,‚à£ciphertext‚à£‚â§106|n|\leq 10^6, |ciphertext|\leq 10^6‚à£n‚à£‚â§106,‚à£ciphertext‚à£‚â§106.

Output Format:

You need to print the decoded message in one line.

Sample Input 1

Sample Input 2

Sample Outputs...?

Whoops, ciphers are no more secret if we tell you the answers! Why not figure out yourself? Hints: the above samples all decode to proper English sentences.

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Chihiro Fujisaki and Keyworded Caesar Cipher

"I'm scared, but...I can handle it. I...don't really understand why, but...

When I think about everyone else, my courage starts to grow...!"

Description:

Monokuma has cracked Chihiro Fujisaki's Caesar Cipher. The Ultimate Programmer Fujisaki is working on a more secure code called "Keyworded Caesar Cipher". Let Fujisaki explain his genius ideas to you:

"My keyworded Caesar cipher no longer has a numerical key, but a keyword, for example, "Wednesday". Just as the original Caesar cipher creates a shifted alphabet for encoding letters, so too does my keyworded Caesar cipher have one, and this encoding alphabet is created by the keyword "Wednesday".

"I first turn all letters into lowercase, and remove duplicate letters in the keyword, keeping only their first occurences. Now "Wednesday" has become "wednsay".

"Then I write the alphabet a through z in one line, and my new keyword "wednsay" beneath it.

a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y zw e d n s a y

"And finally, I fill the rest of my encoding alphabet starting from the last letter y. However, letters in the keyword are already used. I should skip these letters when filling the rest, because I cannot let two letters encode to a same value.

a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y zw e d n s a y z b c f g h i j k l m o p q r t u v x

"Alright. I can use it to encode a to w, z to x, and my name Chihiro to Dzbzbmj! For uppercase letters I can do the same, but not for digits any more. It's no big deal. I know in homework 1 you turned numbers into English words, right? (laughs)"

How nice would it be, if only you and he know the secret! Monokuma has heared all your conversation and learned his new method. More importantly, Monokuma has obtained the keyword! Please help Monokuma again to decrypt Fujisaki's messages.

Input Format:

The input contains two lines:

The first line contains a non-empty string keyword, containing only uppercase and lowercase letters.

The second line contains a non-empty string ciphertext, the encoded text, ending with a line break character ('\n'). Only uppercase and lowercase letters have been encoded.

It is guaranteed that 1‚â§‚à£keyword‚à£‚â§100,‚à£ciphertext‚à£‚â§1061 \leq |keyword|\leq 100,|ciphertext|\leq 10^61‚â§‚à£keyword‚à£‚â§100,‚à£ciphertext‚à£‚â§106.

Output Format:

You need to print the decoded message in one line.

Sample Input 1

Sample Input 2

Sample Input 3

Sample Outputs...?

Secret, of course! Again, they all decode to proper English sentences.

Hints

You may find some functions in <string.h> useful, for example, strlen, strchr, strcmp. Here is a full list of standard library support for string and char manipulations.

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Nagito Komaeda and lucky days

"I believe my actions will become the foundation of this world's hope. And...if that really happens... Praise me."

Description

Some people believe numbers with certain properties, like palindromes, are special, so does Nagito Komaeda. Komaeda wants to choose a date for himself to do some important things. As the Ultimate Lucky Student, he finds the dates he chooses are all palindrome dates. He is very interested in this kind of special dates.

We define a date YYYYMMDD (Y, M, D are digits for year, month, and date) to be a palindrome date if it is palindrome, that is, its digits remain the same after being reversed. For example, we can write Apr. 4th, 2022 as 20220404 and write Dec. 30th, 321 as 03211230 (We also zero-fill the year to make it exactly 888 digits). The date 03211230 is a palindrome date.

However, Komaeda has a special calendar, in which there are a total of mmm months in a year, and the iii-th month will have did_idi‚Äã days. Luckily, there is no leap year(Èó∞Âπ¥) in his calendar, so there is no need to calculate whether a year is a leap year.

Nagito Komaeda wants to know the total number of palindrome dates in a certain time interval. He is so lucky that he can randomly guess out the correct answer, but you cannot. You want to write a program to calculate the number of palindrome dates.

Input Format:

The input contains 4 lines.

In the first line is a number mmm, indicating the number of months each year in the special calendar.

In the second line are mmm numbers separated by spaces. The iii-th number did_idi‚Äã indicates that the iii-th month has did_idi‚Äã days.

In the next two lines, you will get two dates startstartstart and endendend respectively, representing the start date and the end date, in the form of YYYYMMDD.

It is guaranteed that:

  • 1‚â§m‚â§99,1‚â§di‚â§991\leq m\leq99,1\leq d_i\leq 991‚â§m‚â§99,1‚â§di‚Äã‚â§99 .
  • 00010101‚â§start<end‚â§9999999900010101 \leq start < end \leq 9999999900010101‚â§start<end‚â§99999999 .

Output Format:

You only need to output one integer, the number of palindrome dates in the range [start,end][start, end][start,end] (both ends inclusive).

Sample Input:

Sample Output:

Sample Explanation:

There are two palindrome dates between the two dates: 200110022001100220011002 and 201001022010010220100102.

(In this sample, the calendar is exactly "our" calendar!)

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Chiaki Nanami Wants to Play Games

"If you want to believe in someone...you need to overcome doubt first. Belief without doubt...is simply a lie."

Description:

Chiaki Nanami, the Ultimate Gamer, now wants to play games. She has a lot of games in her game console and wants to play some of them. Nanami has marked every game with its game type (like FPS or Rogue-like), represented by an integer. If two game types are marked by the same integer, the two games have the same type and vice versa. Nanami also records the price of each game.

The Ultimate Game Player, Nanami Chiaki, also has her favorite type of games. However, she forgot which type of games is her favorite. She only knows that She loves those games so much that the money she spent on her favorite type of games is over half of the total cost of all games.

Please help Nanami to find her favorite game type.

Input Format:

You will first recieve a number nnn, which indicates the number of games Nanami has. Then in each of the next nnn lines you will recieve a tuple. The tuple(si,pi,ti)(s_i,p_i,t_i)(si‚Äã,pi‚Äã,ti‚Äã) in iii-th line represents the name, price and type of the iii-th game.

It's guaranteed that there will be no comma in sis_isi‚Äã, the game names. The game types may not be consecutive (i.e. the tit_iti‚Äãs may not simply be 1,2,3...1, 2, 3...1,2,3...).

For 100%100\%100% input,

  • 1‚â§n‚â§1061\leq n\leq10^61‚â§n‚â§106
  • 1‚â§pi‚â§2√ó1061 \leq p_i\leq 2\times10^61‚â§pi‚Äã‚â§2√ó106
  • 1‚â§ti‚â§1061\leq t_i\leq 10^61‚â§ti‚Äã‚â§106
  • ‚àëi=1n‚à£si‚à£‚â§107\sum_{i=1}^{n}|s_i|\leq 10^7‚àëi=1n‚Äã‚à£si‚Äã‚à£‚â§107

Output Format:

You only need to print one integer, Nanami's favorite type of games.

Sample Input:

Sample Output:

Sample Explanation:

In the sample given, there are 333 games in Nanami's game console. The cost of game type 111 is 2+3=52+3=52+3=5 and the cost of game type 222 is 444. The cost of game type 111 is over the half of the total cost 4+5=94+5=94+5=9, so her favorite type is 111.

Challenge (Golden Strawberry):

This problem can be solved in a clever way! You don't need to record all games' types and costs into arrays, and in fact you only need very few variables! Can you solve the problem by declaring at most 10 variables (without using arrays or pointers)? Submit your solution to the additional problem 6 to win the golden strawberry award!

Hint: Use the property of the favorite games.

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Gundham Tanaka and the Dark Devas of Destruction

"Pitiful humans...they refuse to lift their heads up for fear of doubting the authenticity of the blue sky..."

Description:

Gundham Tanaka, the Ultimate Breeder, kept a lot of animals, such as hamsters and eagles. He named all his animals respectively (like his four favourite hamsters, "the Four Dark Devas of Destruction"). One day, the "Dark Devas of Destruction" (his hamsters, actually) wanted to play a game with him.

These hamsters form a matrix of rrr rows and ccc columns, but facing to different directions L (left), R (right), U (up), or D (down). Among them are some special hamsters which Tanaka needs to find out.

At first, a leading hamster will hint where the first special hamster is. Whenever he finds a special hamster, it will also hint the position of the next special hamster to him. All hints are in forms like "The next special hamster is the pip_ipi‚Äã-th one in front/back/left/right of me".

The hamsters make mistake sometimes. When a hamster gives a position, if it is out of bound , or if the hamster at that position has already been identified as a special hamster previously, Tanaka will stop the game and tell his hamsters that they have made a mistake.

Now Tanaka is playing the game, please help him find all special hamsters.

Input Format:

In the first line, you will receive 333 numbers r,c,qr,c,qr,c,q, separated by spaces, indicating the number of rows and columns of the hamster matrix, and the number of hints given by hamsters.

In the next rrr lines, you will receive a rrr-row ccc-column word matrix{dij}(dij‚àà{\{d_{ij}\}(d_{ij} \in \{{dij‚Äã}(dij‚Äã‚àà{ L, R, U, D})\})}). dijd_{ij}dij‚Äã represents the direction of the hamster in the iii-th row and jjj-th column, facing L (left), R (right), U (up), or D (down).

In the next line, you will receive 222 numbers rleading,cleadingr_{leading},c_{leading}rleading‚Äã,cleading‚Äã, indicating the row and column of the leading hamster.

In the next qqq lines, each line you will receive a word wi(wi‚àà{w_i(w_{i} \in \{wi‚Äã(wi‚Äã‚àà{ Left, Right, Front, Back })\})}) and an integer pip_ipi‚Äã, meaning that the hint is "The next hamster is the pip_ipi‚Äã-th in wiw_iwi‚Äã of me".

Another thing you need to know: Hamsters are not computers, they count from 111 rather than 000.

It is guaranteed that:

  • 2‚â§r,c‚â§5002 \leq r,c\leq5002‚â§r,c‚â§500
  • 1‚â§q‚â§1000001 \leq q \leq 1000001‚â§q‚â§100000

Output Format:

In each line, you should print (r, c), the row and column of a special hamster, in their order of being found, until the game ends or the last one is found. If the hamsters made mistake in one hint, you should print Mistake! in the corresponding line and end the game.

Sample Input:

Sample Output:

Sample Explanation:

Their directions:

‚Üë ‚Üê
‚Üì ‚Üì

The leading hamster is at (1,1)(1,1)(1,1). It says that the first special hamster is the 111st hamster in its back, at (2,1)(2,1)(2,1).

Notice that the hamster at (2,1)(2,1)(2,1) is facing down, and it says the next special hamster is in its left, which actually means to the right (back's left) of the matrix, which is (2,2)(2,2)(2,2).

The next special hamster is obviously unable to find, so there is a mistake. The game ends, ignoring any more hints from hamsters.

CS100 Homework 2 (Spring 2023)

Deadline: 2023-03-08 (Wed) 23:59:59

Late submission will open for 24 hours after the deadline, with 50% point deduction.

If you get full marks in this assignment by no more than 40 submission attempts, you can earn special OJ displays and a "1-case protection" that can be used in further assignments to cancel one testcase failure. See Piazza or OJ dashboard for more information.

Problem 1: Happy Coding

Given nnn integers, output the square of positive numbers in reversed order.

Input

The first line contains a non-negative integer nnn.

Then nnn lines follow, the iii-th line containing an integer aia_iai‚Äã.

Output

Your output should consist of m+1m+1m+1 lines, where mmm is the number of positive numbers in {a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an}\{a_1,\cdots,a_n\}{a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã}. The first mmm lines contain the square of positive numbers in reversed order, one for each line. Then print mmm on the last line.

Sample

Input

Output

Notes

1‚©Ωn‚©Ω1001\leqslant n\leqslant 1001‚©Ωn‚©Ω100.

‚àí231‚©Ωai‚©Ω231‚àí1-2^{31}\leqslant a_i\leqslant 2^{31}-1‚àí231‚©Ωai‚Äã‚©Ω231‚àí1 for every i‚àà{1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,n}i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}i‚àà{1,‚ãØ,n}

Problem 2: Quadratic Equation

Solving a linear equation is too hard, so we will solve a quadratic equation. A quadratic equation is of the form ax2+bx+c=0ax^2+bx+c=0ax2+bx+c=0, where a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c are constant real numbers and the unknown x‚ààRx\in\mathbb Rx‚ààR.

Given the coefficients a,ba,ba,b and ccc, your task is to solve the quadratic equation ax2+bx+c=0ax^2+bx+c=0ax2+bx+c=0.

To make the problem easier, aaa may be zero. To make the problem harder, it is guaranteed that a,b,c‚ààZa,b,c\in\mathbb Za,b,c‚ààZ.

Solve the equation and output the solution(s).

  • If the equation is a quadratic one, your output should be of one of the following forms (where ??? is replaced with the exact solution):
    • x1 = x2 = ???
    • x1 = ???, x2 = ??? where x1<x2x_1<x_2x1‚Äã<x2‚Äã
    • No solution.
  • Otherwise, your output should be of one of the following forms (where ??? is replaced with the exact solution):
    • x = ???
    • No solution.
    • x\in\mathbb{R}, indicating x‚ààRx\in\mathbb Rx‚ààR in LaTeX\LaTeXLATE‚ÄãX

All the output numbers should be rounded to three decimal places.

It is guaranteed that ‚à£a‚à£,‚à£b‚à£,‚à£c‚à£‚©Ω100|a|,|b|,|c|\leqslant 100‚à£a‚à£,‚à£b‚à£,‚à£c‚à£‚©Ω100.

Problem 3: Hexadecimal Calculator

You are given two integers aaa and bbb in hexadecimal representation. Your task is to perform addition a+ba+ba+b or subtraction a‚àíba-ba‚àíb in hexadecimal using the vertical method (Á´ñÂºè).

Input

Three lines in total.

The first line contains a character that is either '+' or '-', which indicates the operation you need to perform.

The next two lines are the integers aaa and bbb respectively, in hexadecimal representation.

Output

Show how you do the vertical addition/subtraction. Your output should be of one of the following forms:

where the x's and y's represent the input numbers aaa and bbb, and p is either + or - depending on the input.

Samples

Notes

Let L(x)L(x)L(x) be the length of the hexadecimal representation (i.e. the number of digits required) of xxx. Let rrr be the result (either a+ba+ba+b or a‚àíba-ba‚àíb). It is guaranteed that

  • a,b,r‚©æ0a,b,r\geqslant 0a,b,r‚©æ0.
  • L(a),L(b)‚©Ω50L(a),L(b)\leqslant 50L(a),L(b)‚©Ω50.
  • L(r)‚©Ωmax‚Å°{L(a),L(b)}L(r)\leqslant\max\{L(a),L(b)\}L(r)‚©Ωmax{L(a),L(b)}.

Problem 4: Bit Operation

Background (You can skip this entire section)

In the year 1979, a young astronomer named Ye Wenjie is working on a project that aims to send radio signals to outer space in search of extraterrestrial intelligence. Ye Wenjie is a survivor of the Chinese Cultural Revolution, a period of political turmoil and violence that killed her father and traumatized her. She has lost faith in humanity and hopes to find a better civilization in the stars.

Ye Wenjie‚Äôs project is supported by a secret military base called Red Coast. The base has a powerful antenna that can transmit and receive signals from distant galaxies. Ye Wenjie uses the antenna to send messages to various star systems, hoping to get a response. She also receives messages from other human radio stations around the world.

One day, she receives a message from an unknown source that gives her a coding problem as a way of testing her intelligence and curiosity. The problem is in the discription.

Ye Wenjie solves the problem using her knowledge of binary arithmetic and sends her code back to the source. She thinks that by doing so she can establish contact with an alien civilization and learn more about their culture and technology. She doesn‚Äôt know that by doing so she has also invited a hostile invasion from a ruthless enemy‚Ä¶

Description

In this problem, your task is to split a number into two parts by binary digits and reassemble them to form a new number.

You will recieve an unsigned integer xxx whose binary representation consists of nnn digits (You need to find nnn on yourself!), and a non-negative integer mmm. First, you need to split out the rightmost m+1m+1m+1 digits to form an integer ppp, and the rest digits form an integer qqq. Then, place ppp on the left of qqq (in binary representation) to obtain a new number.

Formally, write xxx as

x=(xn‚àí1‚Ä¶x1x0)twox=(x_{n-1}\dots x_1x_0)_{\text{two}}x=(xn‚àí1‚Äã‚Ä¶x1‚Äãx0‚Äã)two‚Äã

where xi‚àà{0,1}x_i\in\{0,1\}xi‚Äã‚àà{0,1} and xn‚àí1=1x_{n-1}=1xn‚àí1‚Äã=1. Then

p=(xm‚Ä¶x1x0)two,andq=(xn‚àí1‚Ä¶xm+1)two.p=(x_{m}\dots x_1x_0)_{\text{two}},\quad\text{and}\quad q=(x_{n-1}\dots x_{m+1})_{\text{two}}.p=(xm‚Äã‚Ä¶x1‚Äãx0‚Äã)two‚Äã,andq=(xn‚àí1‚Äã‚Ä¶xm+1‚Äã)two‚Äã.

The reassembled integer should be

y=(xm‚Ä¶x1x0xn‚àí1‚Ä¶xm+1)two.y=(x_{m}\dots x_1x_0x_{n-1}\dots x_{m+1})_{\text{two}}.y=(xm‚Äã‚Ä¶x1‚Äãx0‚Äãxn‚àí1‚Äã‚Ä¶xm+1‚Äã)two‚Äã.

Then, you need to calculate the "lowbit" of yyy. The "lowbit" of an integer k=(kn‚àí1‚Ä¶k1k0)twok=(k_{n-1}\dots k_1k_0)_{\text{two}}k=(kn‚àí1‚Äã‚Ä¶k1‚Äãk0‚Äã)two‚Äã is the smallest index ttt such that kt=1k_t=1kt‚Äã=1.

For example, if x=54=(110110)twox=54=(110110)_{\text{two}}x=54=(110110)two‚Äã and m=1m=1m=1, ppp should be (10)two(10)_{\text{two}}(10)two‚Äã and qqq is (1101)two(1101)_{\text{two}}(1101)two‚Äã in binary representation. So the reassembled integer is y=(101101)two=45y=(101101)_{\text{two}}=45y=(101101)two‚Äã=45. The "lowbit" of yyy is 000 since the rightmost bit of yyy is 111.

Input

One line containing two integers xxx and mmm, separated by a space.

Output

Two integers yyy and bbb on the same line, separated by a space. yyy is the reassembled integer (in decimal representation) and bbb is the lowbit of yyy.

Samples

Sample 1

Input

Output

Sample 2

Input

Output

Notes

0<x‚©Ω263‚àí10 < x \leqslant 2^{63}-10<x‚©Ω263‚àí1

0‚©Ωm‚©Ω610 \leqslant m\leqslant 610‚©Ωm‚©Ω61

It is guaranteed that m‚©Ωn‚àí2m\leqslant n-2m‚©Ωn‚àí2.

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Problem 5: No-Horse Sudoku

"No-horse sudoku", as interesting as its name sounds (especially in Chinese), is a kind of irregular sudoku with new rules. In this problem, your goal is to judge whether a given board of "no-horse sudoku" is valid.

Rules

A regular sudoku has 3 rules:

  • Every number should appear exactly once in a column.
  • Every number should appear exactly once in a row.
  • Every number should appear exactly once in a "palace" (any of the nine equally divided 3√ó33\times33√ó3 regions).

For "no-horse sudoku", we have an additional rule related to a concept "horse step".

Similar to the rules of horses in chess, we define that two grids share a "horse step" if they lie diagonally in a 2√ó32 \times 32√ó3 or 3√ó23 \times 23√ó2 rectangle (The pair (E5, C4), for example).

Now here comes the additional rule:

  • Any two grids sharing a "horse step" should not be filled in with the same number.

Your Task

Write a program that reads in an entire sudoku board and judges whether the board is valid under the "no-horse sudoku" rules. The whole board is valid if and only if all the numbers in the grids are valid.

It is recommended that you implement such a function (or anything similar to this), which can help you make your code clear and readable.

  • Brief: Judges whether the number in the grid board[row][col] is valid under the "no-horse sudoku" rules.
  • Parameters:
    • board: a 9√ó99\times 99√ó9 array representing the sudoku board
    • row: the row index of the target grid
    • col: the column index of the target grid
  • Return value: true if the number in that grid is valid, false otherwise.

Input:

999 lines, each line containing 999 numbers separated by space, representing a row of the sudoku board. The iii-th line of the input represents the iii-th row (top to bottom) in the sudoku board.

Output:

1 or 0. Output 1 if the board is valid, and 0 otherwise.

Important Note

We will check whether you earned your score for this problem in a proper way. Some tricks may get you a high score on OJ, but it will be in vain in the end.

    ÂΩì n=abn = abn=ab ‰∏î aaa Âíå bbb ‰∫íË¥®Êó∂ÔºåÊúâ œÜ(n)=œÜ(ab)=œÜ(a)‚ãÖœÜ(b)=(a‚àí1)‚ãÖ(b‚àí1)\varphi(n) = \varphi(ab) = \varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b) = (a-1) \cdot (b-1)œÜ(n)=œÜ(ab)=œÜ(a)‚ãÖœÜ(b)=(a‚àí1)‚ãÖ(b‚àí1)„ÄÇÂõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÂæóÂà∞ ‚àÄa,b‚ààZ+\forall a,b \in \mathbb{Z}^+‚àÄa,b‚ààZ+ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú aaa Âíå bbb ‰∫íË¥®ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊúâ a(b‚àí1)(a‚àí1)‚â°1(modab)a^{(b-1)(a-1)} \equiv 1 \pmod {ab}a(b‚àí1)(a‚àí1)‚â°1(modab)ÔºåÂç≥

    œÜ(ab)=(a‚àí1)√ó(b‚àí1)\varphi(ab) = (a-1) \times (b-1)œÜ(ab)=(a‚àí1)√ó(b‚àí1)

  1. 1.ËøôÊòØ‰∏≠ÂõΩÂâ©‰ΩôÂÆöÁêÜÔºàChinese Remainder TheoremÔºâÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁâπÊÆäÊÉÖÂÜµÔºå‰πüË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫‚ÄúÂçïËß£Âêå‰ΩôÊñπÁ®ãÂÆöÁêÜ‚ÄùÔºàTheorem of Single Solution of Congruence EquationÔºâÊàñ‚ÄúËæóËΩ¨Áõ∏Èô§Ê≥ï‚ÄùÔºàMethod of Successive DivisionÔºâ‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê≠•È™§„ÄÇ ‚Ü©

entry.content:
ÂØπÂ∫î„ÄäÂ§ßÂ≠¶Êï∞Â≠¶ ÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ ‰∏ã„ÄãÔºö‚Äú8.6 ÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞ÂíåÊ¢ØÂ∫¶‚Äù

Êú¨ÁØáÂÜÖÂÆπ

ÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞

1. ‰ΩøÁî®ÂêëÈáèÂÆö‰πâ

ÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞ÊòØÊèèËø∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞Ê≤øÁùÄÊüê‰∏™ÁªôÂÆöÊñπÂêëÁöÑÂèòÂåñÈÄüÁéáÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂÅáËÆæ z=f(x,y)z=f(x,y)z=f(x,y) ÊòØÂÆö‰πâÂú®Âπ≥Èù¢‰∏äÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåP0(x0,y0)P_0(x_0,y_0)P0‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã) ÊòØÂπ≥Èù¢‰∏äÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÔºåv‚Éó=(a,b)\vec{v}=(a,b)v=(a,b) ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÈõ∂ÂêëÈáè„ÄÇÈÇ£‰πàÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÁÇπ P0P_0P0‚Äã Ê≤øÁùÄÊñπÂêë v‚Éó\vec{v}v ÁöÑÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞ Dv‚Éóf(x0,y0)D_{\vec{v}}f(x_0,y_0)Dv‚Äãf(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã) ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏∫Ôºö

Dv‚Éóf(x0,y0)=lim‚Å°h‚Üí0f(x0+ha,y0+hb)‚àíf(x0,y0)hD_{\vec{v}}f(x_0,y_0)=\lim_{h\to 0}\frac{f(x_0+ha,y_0+hb)-f(x_0,y_0)}{h}Dv‚Äãf(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)=h‚Üí0lim‚Äãhf(x0‚Äã+ha,y0‚Äã+hb)‚àíf(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)‚Äã

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Ôºåhhh ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆûÊï∞ÔºåË°®Á§∫Ê≤øÁùÄÊñπÂêë v‚Éó\vec{v}v ÂâçËøõÁöÑË∑ùÁ¶ª„ÄÇÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫ÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÁÇπ P0P_0P0‚Äã Â§ÑÊ≤øÁùÄÂçï‰ΩçÂêëÈáè u‚Éó\vec{u}u ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ u‚Éó\vec{u}u ‰∏é v‚Éó\vec{v}v ÊñπÂêëÁõ∏Âêå„ÄÇ

‰ª•‰∏äÊòØÈÄöËøá‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊñπÂêëÂêëÈáèÊù•ÂÆö‰πâÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËøòËÉΩÂºïÂÖ• ÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶ Êù•Êõ¥Âä†Ê∏ÖÊô∞Âú∞ÊèèËø∞

2. ‰ΩøÁî®ÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶ÂÆö‰πâ

È¶ñÂÖàÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÂÖàÊòéÁôΩ‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶

ÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶:

ÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶ÊòØÊèèËø∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÂú®ÂêÑ‰∏™ÂùêÊ†áËΩ¥‰∏äÁöÑÊäïÂΩ±ÂàÜÈáè‰∏éÂêëÈáèÈïøÂ∫¶‰πãÊØîÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂÅáËÆæÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ nnn Áª¥ÂêëÈáè v‚Éó=(v1,v2,‚Ä¶,vn)\vec{v}=(v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n)v=(v1‚Äã,v2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,vn‚Äã)ÔºåÂàôÂêëÈáè v‚Éó\vec{v}v Âú®Á¨¨ iii ‰∏™ÂùêÊ†áËΩ¥‰∏äÁöÑÊäïÂΩ±ÂàÜÈáèÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫ vicos‚Å°Œ∏iv_i\cos\theta_ivi‚ÄãcosŒ∏i‚ÄãÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ Œ∏i\theta_iŒ∏i‚Äã ÊòØÂêëÈáè v‚Éó\vec{v}v ‰∏éÁ¨¨ iii ‰∏™ÂùêÊ†áËΩ¥‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÂ§πËßí„ÄÇ

Âõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÂêëÈáè v‚Éó\vec{v}v Âú®Á¨¨ iii ‰∏™ÂùêÊ†áËΩ¥‰∏äÁöÑÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶ cos‚Å°Œ∏i\cos\theta_icosŒ∏i‚Äã ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏∫Ôºö

cos‚Å°Œ∏i=vi‚à£v‚Éó‚à£=viv12+v22+‚ãØ+vn2\cos\theta_i=\frac{v_i}{|\vec{v}|}=\frac{v_i}{\sqrt{v_1^2+v_2^2+\cdots+v_n^2}}cosŒ∏i‚Äã=‚à£v‚à£vi‚Äã‚Äã=v12‚Äã+v22‚Äã+‚ãØ+vn2‚Äã‚Äãvi‚Äã‚Äã

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ ‚à£v‚Éó‚à£|\vec{v}|‚à£v‚à£ Ë°®Á§∫ÂêëÈáè v‚Éó\vec{v}v ÁöÑÈïøÂ∫¶Ôºå‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫ ‚à£v‚Éó‚à£=v12+v22+‚ãØ+vn2|\vec{v}|=\sqrt{v_1^2+v_2^2+\cdots+v_n^2}‚à£v‚à£=v12‚Äã+v22‚Äã+‚ãØ+vn2‚Äã‚Äã„ÄÇ

Êé•‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰æøÂèØ‰ª•ÂÄüÁî®ÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶Êù•ÂÆö‰πâÊñπÂêëÂáΩÊï∞

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂÅáËÆæ z=f(x,y)z=f(x,y)z=f(x,y) ÊòØÂÆö‰πâÂú®Âπ≥Èù¢‰∏äÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåP0(x0,y0)P_0(x_0,y_0)P0‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã) ÊòØÂπ≥Èù¢‰∏äÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÔºåv‚Éó=(a,b)\vec{v}=(a,b)v=(a,b) ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÈõ∂ÂêëÈáè„ÄÇÈÇ£‰πàÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÁÇπ P0P_0P0‚Äã Ê≤øÁùÄÊñπÂêë v‚Éó\vec{v}v ÁöÑÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞ Dv‚Éóf(x0,y0)D_{\vec{v}}f(x_0,y_0)Dv‚Äãf(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã) ÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫Ôºö

Dv‚Éóf(x0,y0)=‚àÇf‚àÇx(x0,y0)cos‚Å°Œ±+‚àÇf‚àÇy(x0,y0)cos‚Å°Œ≤D_{\vec{v}}f(x_0,y_0)=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0,y_0)\cos\alpha+\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0,y_0)\cos\betaDv‚Äãf(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)=‚àÇx‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)cosŒ±+‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)cosŒ≤

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÔºåŒ±\alphaŒ± Âíå Œ≤\betaŒ≤ ÊòØÂêëÈáè v‚Éó\vec{v}v ÁöÑÊñπÂêë‰ΩôÂº¶„ÄÇ

Ê¢ØÂ∫¶

1. Ê¶ÇÂøµ

Ê¢ØÂ∫¶ÁöÑÊú¨ÊÑèÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÔºåË°®Á§∫Êüê‰∏ÄÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÁÇπÂ§ÑÁöÑÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞Ê≤øÁùÄËØ•ÊñπÂêëÂèñÂæóÊúÄÂ§ßÂÄºÔºåÂç≥ÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÁÇπÂ§ÑÊ≤øÁùÄËØ•ÊñπÂêëÔºàÊ≠§Ê¢ØÂ∫¶ÁöÑÊñπÂêëÔºâÂèòÂåñÊúÄÂø´ÔºåÂèòÂåñÁéáÊúÄÂ§ßÔºà‰∏∫ËØ•Ê¢ØÂ∫¶ÁöÑÊ®°Ôºâ„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú f(x,y,z)f(x,y,z)f(x,y,z) ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèØÂæÆÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÂú®ÁÇπ (x0,y0,z0)(x_0,y_0,z_0)(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã,z0‚Äã) Â§ÑÁöÑÊ¢ØÂ∫¶‰∏∫Ôºö

‚àáf(x0,y0,z0)=(‚àÇf‚àÇx(x0,y0,z0),‚àÇf‚àÇy(x0,y0,z0),‚àÇf‚àÇz(x0,y0,z0))\nabla f(x_0,y_0,z_0) = (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0,y_0,z_0),\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0,y_0,z_0),\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x_0,y_0,z_0))‚àáf(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã,z0‚Äã)=(‚àÇx‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã,z0‚Äã),‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã,z0‚Äã),‚àÇz‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã,z0‚Äã))

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Ôºå‚àÇf‚àÇx\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}‚àÇx‚àÇf‚ÄãÔºå‚àÇf‚àÇy\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äã Âíå ‚àÇf‚àÇz\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}‚àÇz‚àÇf‚Äã ÂàÜÂà´Ë°®Á§∫ÂáΩÊï∞ fff Âú® xxxÔºåyyy Âíå zzz ÊñπÂêë‰∏äÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞„ÄÇ

ËøôÈáåÁöÑ ‚àá=(‚àÇ‚àÇx,¬†‚àÇ‚àÇy,¬†‚àÇ‚àÇz)\nabla =(\frac{\partial}{\partial x},\ \frac{\partial}{\partial y},\ \frac{\partial}{\partial z})‚àá=(‚àÇx‚àÇ‚Äã,¬†‚àÇy‚àÇ‚Äã,¬†‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äã) ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ ÁÆóÂ≠ê „ÄÇ

ÁÆóÂ≠êÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÊò†Â∞ÑÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Â∞Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÁ©∫Èó¥ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†Êò†Â∞ÑÂà∞Âè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÁ©∫Èó¥Ôºà‰πüÊúâÂèØËÉΩÊòØÁõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÂêëÈáèÁ©∫Èó¥Ôºâ‰∏≠ÁöÑÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇÁÆÄÂçïÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÁÆóÂ≠êÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞Á©∫Èó¥Âà∞ÂáΩÊï∞Á©∫Èó¥‰∏äÁöÑÊò†Â∞Ñ„ÄÇ

Êàë‰ª¨ËøòÂèØ‰ª•‰ªéÁâ©ÁêÜÁöÑËßíÂ∫¶Êù•ËÄÉÂØüÊ¢ØÂ∫¶ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµ
È¶ñÂÖàÊàë‰ª¨ÂÖàÁêÜËß£‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÁâ©ÁêÜ‰∏≠ÁöÑÂú∫Ôºö

Áâ©ÁêÜÂ≠¶‰∏≠ÁöÑ Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫ Âíå ÂêëÈáèÂú∫ ÊÄªÁß∞‰∏∫ Âú∫

Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫

Âú®Áâ©ÁêÜÂ≠¶‰∏≠ÔºåÊï∞ÈáèÂú∫ÊòØÊåáÊüê‰∏™Áâ©ÁêÜÈáèÂú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÁöÑÂèñÂÄºÈöèÁùÄ‰ΩçÁΩÆÁöÑÂèòÂåñËÄåÂèòÂåñÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåËøô‰∏™Áâ©ÁêÜÈáèÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØÊ†áÈáèÊàñÁü¢Èáè„ÄÇ

‰ª•Ê†áÈáèÂú∫‰∏∫‰æãÔºåÂÅáËÆæÂú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏äÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê†áÈáèÂÄºÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÊ∏©Â∫¶„ÄÅÂØÜÂ∫¶„ÄÅÂéãÂäõ„ÄÅËÉΩÈáèÂØÜÂ∫¶Á≠â„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÁâ©ÁêÜÈáèÂèØ‰ª•Áî®Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫Êù•ÊèèËø∞ÔºåÂç≥Âú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆûÊï∞ÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y,z)f(x,y,z)f(x,y,z)ÔºåË°®Á§∫Âú®ÁÇπ (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) Â§ÑÁöÑÁâ©ÁêÜÈáèÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞è„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÊ∏©Â∫¶Âú∫ÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫ T(x,y,z)T(x,y,z)T(x,y,z)ÔºåËÉΩÈáèÂØÜÂ∫¶Âú∫ÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫ œÅ(x,y,z)\rho(x,y,z)œÅ(x,y,z)„ÄÇÊï∞ÈáèÂú∫ÁöÑÁâ©ÁêÜÂê´‰πâÊòØÔºåÂú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏äÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆûÊï∞ÂÄºÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂÄºË°®Á§∫‰∫ÜÊüêÁßçÁâ©ÁêÜÈáèÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞èÊàñÂº∫Â∫¶„ÄÇ

ÂêëÈáèÂú∫

Âú®Áâ©ÁêÜÂ≠¶‰∏≠ÔºåÂêëÈáèÂú∫ÊòØÊåáÂú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏äÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáè‰∏é‰πãÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÇËøô‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÁöÑÊüê‰∏™Áâ©ÁêÜÈáèÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞èÂíåÊñπÂêëÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÈÄüÂ∫¶„ÄÅÂäõ„ÄÅÁ£ÅÂú∫Á≠â„ÄÇ

‰ª•ÈÄüÂ∫¶Âú∫‰∏∫‰æãÔºåÂÅáËÆæÂú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏äÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈÄüÂ∫¶ÂêëÈáèÔºåË°®Á§∫ÊµÅ‰ΩìÊàñÊ∞î‰ΩìÂú®ËØ•ÁÇπÁöÑÈÄüÂ∫¶Â§ßÂ∞èÂíåÊñπÂêë„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÈÄüÂ∫¶ÂêëÈáèÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÂêëÈáèÂú∫Êù•ÊèèËø∞ÔºåÂç≥Âú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÂáΩÊï∞ v‚Éó(x,y,z)\vec{v}(x,y,z)v(x,y,z)ÔºåË°®Á§∫Âú®ÁÇπ (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) Â§ÑÁöÑÈÄüÂ∫¶ÂêëÈáè„ÄÇÂêëÈáèÂú∫ÁöÑÁâ©ÁêÜÂê´‰πâÊòØÔºåÂú®Á©∫Èó¥‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏äÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂêëÈáèË°®Á§∫‰∫ÜÊüêÁßçÁâ©ÁêÜÈáèÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞èÂíåÊñπÂêë„ÄÇ

Êúâ‰∫õÂú∫‰∏ç‰ªÖÂíåÁ©∫Èó¥ÊúâÂÖ≥ÔºåËøòÂíåÊó∂Èó¥ÊúâÂÖ≥Ôºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÂú∫ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÊ∑ªÂä†‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúâÂÖ≥Êó∂Èó¥ÁöÑËá™ÂèòÈáè ttt„ÄÇ
Êàë‰ª¨Áß∞ÂíåÊó∂Èó¥Êó†ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂú∫‰∏∫ Á®≥ÂÆöÂú∫„ÄÇ

ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫ f(x,y,z)f(x,y,z)f(x,y,z)ÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÂØπÂ∫î Ê¢ØÂ∫¶Âú∫ ‚àáf\nabla f‚àáf ÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêëÈáèÂú∫ÔºåÂÆÉÂú®ÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπ (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z) Â§ÑÁöÑÂÄº‰∏∫Ôºö

‚àáf=(fx,¬†fy,¬†fz)\nabla f = (f_x,\ f_y,\ f_z)‚àáf=(fx‚Äã,¬†fy‚Äã,¬†fz‚Äã)

2. ÊÑè‰πâ

Ê¢ØÂ∫¶ÁöÑÊñπÂêëÂ∞±ÊòØÂèòÂåñÁéáÊúÄÂ§ßÁöÑÊñπÂêëÔºåËÄåÊ¢ØÂ∫¶ÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞èÂàôË°®Á§∫ÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÊñπÂêë‰∏äÁöÑÂèòÂåñÁéá„ÄÇ

3. ËøêÁÆóÊÄßË¥®

  1. Á∫øÊÄßÊÄßË¥®

    ËÆæ fff Âíå ggg ÊòØ‰∏§‰∏™Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫ÔºåŒ±\alphaŒ± Âíå Œ≤\betaŒ≤ ÊòØ‰∏§‰∏™Â∏∏Êï∞ÔºåÂàôÊúâ

    ‚àá(Œ±f+Œ≤g)=Œ±‚àáf+Œ≤‚àág\nabla(\alpha f + \beta g) = \alpha \nabla f + \beta \nabla g‚àá(Œ±f+Œ≤g)=Œ±‚àáf+Œ≤‚àág

    Ëøô‰∏™ÊÄßË¥®ÂèØ‰ª•Á±ªÊØîÂØºÊï∞ÁöÑÁ∫øÊÄßÊÄßË¥®„ÄÇ

  2. ‰πòÁßØÊ≥ïÂàô

    ËÆæ fff Âíå ggg ÊòØ‰∏§‰∏™Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫ÔºåÂàôÊúâ

    ‚àá(fg)=f‚àág+g‚àáf\nabla(fg) = f \nabla g + g \nabla f‚àá(fg)=f‚àág+g‚àáf

    Ëøô‰∏™ÊÄßË¥®ÂèØ‰ª•Á±ªÊØîÊ±ÇÂØºÊï∞ÁöÑ‰πòÁßØÊ≥ïÂàô„ÄÇ

  3. ÂÅèÂØºÊï∞‰∫§Êç¢Âæã

    ËÆæ fff ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞ÈáèÂú∫Ôºåxxx Âíå yyy ÊòØ‰∏§‰∏™Ëá™ÂèòÈáèÔºåÂàôÊúâ

    ‚àÇ2f‚àÇx‚àÇy=‚àÇ2f‚àÇy‚àÇx\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x \partial y} = \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y \partial x}‚àÇx‚àÇy‚àÇ2f‚Äã=‚àÇy‚àÇx‚àÇ2f‚Äã

    Âç≥

    fxy=fyxf_{xy} = f_{yx}fxy‚Äã=fyx‚Äã

    Ëøô‰∏™ÊÄßË¥®Ë°®ÊòéÔºåÂØπ‰∫éÂÖâÊªëÁöÑÊï∞ÈáèÂú∫ fffÔºåÂÅèÂØºÊï∞ÁöÑÊ¨°Â∫èÂèØ‰ª•‰∫§Êç¢„ÄÇ

entry.title: CS50X Note [1]
entry.content:
CS50XÊòØÊàëÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÁßëÂ≠¶ÂêØËíôËØæÔºåÊàëÂêëÊù•‰∏çÈÅó‰ΩôÂäõÂú∞Âêë‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏Ä‰ΩçÊÉ≥ÊâìÂ•ΩÂü∫Á°ÄÁöÑÊñ∞‰∫∫Êé®ËçêËøôÈó®ËØæÁ®ã

Êú¨ÁØáÂú®CS50XÂÆòÁΩëÁöÑËã±ÊñáÂéüÁâà

Lecture 1

ÁÇπÂáªÂàóË°®‰∏≠‰ªªÊÑèÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÂèØË∑≥ËΩ¨Âà∞ÂéüÁâàÂØπÂ∫îÈÉ®ÂàÜ

  • Welcome!
  • Hello World
  • Functions [ÂáΩÊï∞]
  • Variables [ÂèòÈáè]
  • Conditionals [Êù°‰ª∂]
  • Loops [Âæ™ÁéØ]
  • Linux and the Command Line [LinuxÁ≥ªÁªüÂíåÂëΩ‰ª§Ë°å]
  • Mario
  • Comments [Ê≥®Èáä]
  • Abstraction [ÊäΩË±° | Â∞ÅË£Ö]
  • Operators and Types [ËøêÁÆóÁ¨¶ÂíåÁ±ªÂûã]
  • Summing Up

Welcome!

  • Âú®Êàë‰ª¨‰πãÂâçÁöÑËØæÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â≠¶‰π†‰∫ÜScratchÔºå‰∏ÄÁßçÂèØËßÜÂåñÁºñÁ®ãËØ≠Ë®Ä„ÄÇ
  • ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÔºåÂΩì‰Ω†Â≠¶‰π†‰ªª‰ΩïÁºñÁ®ãËØ≠Ë®ÄÊó∂ÔºåScratch‰∏≠‰ΩìÁé∞ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÂü∫Êú¨ÁºñÁ®ãÊ¶ÇÂøµÈÉΩ‰ºöË¢´Áî®‰∏ä„ÄÇ
  • ËØ∑ËÆ∞‰ΩèÔºåËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Âè™ËÉΩÁêÜËß£ ‰∫åËøõÂà∂‰ª£Á†ÅÔºàbinary codeÔºâ„ÄÇÂú®‰∫∫Á±ªÁºñÂÜôÁöÑ Ê∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÔºàsource codeÔºâ ‰∏≠ÔºåÂåÖÂê´‰∫ÜËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÂèØ‰ª•ËØªÊáÇÁöÑÊåá‰ª§ÈõÜÔºåËÄåËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Âè™ËÉΩÁêÜËß£Êàë‰ª¨Áé∞Âú®ÊâÄÁß∞ÁöÑ Êú∫Âô®‰ª£Á†ÅÔºàmachine codeÔºâ„ÄÇÊú∫Âô®‰ª£Á†ÅÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏≤‰ª•ÁâπÂÆöÊ®°ÂºèÁªÑÊàêÁöÑ1Âíå0ÔºõËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÈÄöËøáÊâßË°åÂÆÉÔºåÂèØ‰ª•‰∫ßÁîüÊàë‰ª¨Âú®ÁºñÂÜôÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÊó∂ÊâÄÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÁöÑÊïàÊûú„ÄÇ
  • ‰∫ãÂÆûËØÅÊòéÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®‰∏ÄÁßçÁâπÊÆäÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂Âè´ÂÅö ÁºñËØëÂô®ÔºàcompilerÔºâ Êù•Â∞ÜÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅËΩ¨Êç¢‰∏∫Êú∫Âô®‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇ‰ªäÂ§©ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∞ÜÂêë‰Ω†‰ªãÁªç‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁºñËØëÂô®[1]ÔºåÂÆÉÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©‰Ω†Â∞ÜÁî® C ËØ≠Ë®ÄÂÜôÁöÑÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅËΩ¨Êç¢‰∏∫Êú∫Âô®‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇ
  • ‰ªäÂ§©ÔºåÈô§‰∫ÜÂ≠¶‰π†Â¶Ç‰ΩïÁºñÁ®ãÂ§ñÔºå‰Ω†ËøòÂ∞ÜÂ≠¶‰π†Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂÜôÂá∫Â•ΩÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇ
  • ‰ª£Á†ÅÂèØ‰ª•‰ªé‰∏â‰∏™ÊñπÈù¢ËøõË°åËØÑ‰º∞„ÄÇÈ¶ñÂÖàÔºåÊ≠£Á°ÆÔºàcorrectnessÔºâ ÊåáÁöÑÊòØ ‚Äú‰ª£Á†ÅÊòØÂê¶ÊåâÁÖßÈ¢ÑÊúüËøêË°åÔºü‚Äù ÂÖ∂Ê¨°ÔºåËÆæËÆ°ÔºàdesignÔºâ ÊåáÁöÑÊòØ ‚Äú‰ª£Á†ÅËÆæËÆ°ÂæóÊúâÂ§öÂ•ΩÔºü‚Äù ÊúÄÂêéÔºå È£éÊ†ºÔºàstyleÔºâ ÊåáÁöÑÊòØ‚Äú‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÁæéËßÇÁ®ãÂ∫¶Âíå‰∏ÄËá¥ÊÄßÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÔºü‚Äù

Hello World

  • Êú¨ËØæÁ®ã‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑIDE[2]ÊòØVisual Studio Code ÔºåÈÄöÂ∏∏ÁÆÄÁß∞‰∏∫VS Code „ÄÇ

  • Êàë‰ª¨‰πãÊâÄ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®VS Code ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúÄÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÊòØÂÆÉÂ∑≤ÁªèÈ¢ÑË£Ö‰∫ÜÊú¨ËØæÁ®ãÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑÊâÄÊúâËΩØ‰ª∂ÔºåÂåÖÊã¨‰πãÂâçÊèêÂà∞ÁöÑÁºñËØëÂô®„ÄÇÊú¨ËØæÁ®ãÂíåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂëΩ‰ª§Ë°åÊåá‰ª§ÂùáÊòØ‰ª•VS Code ‰∏∫Âü∫Á°ÄËÆæËÆ°ÁöÑÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§ÊúÄÂ•ΩÂßãÁªà‰ΩøÁî®VS Code ÂÆåÊàêÊú¨ËØæÁ®ãÁöÑ‰Ωú‰∏ö„ÄÇ

  • ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøácode.cs50.ioÊâìÂºÄVS Code ÁöÑÂú®Á∫øÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇ

  • VS Code ÂèØ‰ª•Ë¢´ÂàÜ‰∏∫Â§ö‰∏™Âå∫ÂüüÔºö

    ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÂ∑¶‰æßÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂ËµÑÊ∫êÁÆ°ÁêÜÂô® Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÊâæÂà∞‰Ω†ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºå‰∏≠Èó¥Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áß∞‰∏∫ÊñáÊú¨ÁºñËæëÂô® ÁöÑÂå∫ÂüüÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁºñËæë‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇÊúÄÂêéÔºåÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áß∞‰∏∫ ÂëΩ‰ª§Ë°åÁïåÈù¢ ÁöÑÂå∫ÂüüÔºå‰πüÁß∞‰∏∫CLIÔºåÂëΩ‰ª§Ë°å ÊàñÁªàÁ´ØÁ™óÂè£ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Âêë‰∫ëÊúçÂä°Âô®‰∏äÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÂèëÈÄÅÂëΩ‰ª§„ÄÇ

  • Êàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂú®ÁªàÁ´ØÁ™óÂè£ËæìÂÖ• code hello.c Êù•ÁºñÂÜô C ËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÊïÖÊÑèÂØπÊñá‰ª∂Âè™‰ΩøÁî®Â∞èÂÜôÂëΩÂêçÔºåÂåÖÊã¨ .c Êâ©Â±ïÂêç„ÄÇÊé•‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÂú®Âá∫Áé∞ÁöÑÊñáÊú¨ÁºñËæëÂô®‰∏≠ÁºñÂÜô‰ª•‰∏ã‰ª£Á†ÅÔºö

    Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºå‰∏äËø∞ÊØè‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶ÈÉΩÊúâÂÖ∂ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ËæìÈîô‰∫ÜÔºåÁ®ãÂ∫èÂ∞ÜÊó†Ê≥ïËøêË°å„ÄÇ

  • ÁÇπÂáªÁªàÁ´ØÁ™óÂè£Êù•ÂõûÂà∞ÂÆÉ‰πãÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÊâßË°å make hello Êù•ÁºñËØë‰Ω†ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁúÅÁï•‰∫Ü .c „ÄÇ make ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëá™Âä®ÁºñËØëÊâßË°åÂô®ÔºåÂÆÉ‰ºöÊü•ÊâæÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ hello.c Êñá‰ª∂Âπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ËΩ¨Êç¢‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Âêç‰∏∫ hello ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÊâßË°åÊ≠§ÂëΩ‰ª§ÂêéÊ≤°Êúâ‰ªª‰ΩïÈîôËØØÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÁªßÁª≠„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÊúâÈîôËØØÔºåËØ∑‰ªîÁªÜÊ£ÄÊü•‰Ω†ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÁ°Æ‰øùÂÖ∂‰∏é‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑÁõ∏ÂåπÈÖç„ÄÇ

  • Áé∞Âú®ÔºåËØ∑ËæìÂÖ• ./hello ÂëΩ‰ª§Ôºå‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫èÂ∞Ü‰ºöË¢´ÊâßË°åÔºåÂπ∂ÊâìÂç∞Âá∫ hello, world „ÄÇ

  • Áé∞Âú®ÔºåÂú®Â∑¶‰æßÊâìÂºÄÊñá‰ª∂ËµÑÊ∫êÁÆ°ÁêÜÂô® „ÄÇ‰Ω†‰ºöÊ≥®ÊÑèÂà∞Áé∞Âú®Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âêç‰∏∫ hello.c ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ÂíåÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™Âêç‰∏∫helloÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇhello.c ÂèØ‰ª•Ë¢´ÁºñËØëÂô®ËØªÂèñÔºöÂÆÉÊòØ‰øùÂ≠ò‰Ω†‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ hello ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèØÊâßË°åÊñá‰ª∂Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ËøêË°åÂÆÉÔºå‰ΩÜÁºñËØëÂô®Êó†Ê≥ïËØªÂèñÂÆÉ„ÄÇ

  • ËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨‰ªîÁªÜÂú∞Áúã‰∏Ä‰∏ãÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÔºö

    ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅË¢´ËøõË°å‰∫ÜËØ≠Ê≥ïÈ´ò‰∫Æ[3]„ÄÇ

Functions [ÂáΩÊï∞]

  • Âú®Scratch‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰ΩøÁî® say ÁßØÊú®ÂùóÂú®Â±èÂπï‰∏äÊòæÁ§∫ÊñáÊú¨„ÄÇËÄåÂú® C ËØ≠Ë®Ä‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ë¢´Áß∞‰∏∫ printf ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÂÅöÂà∞ÂêåÊ†∑ÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖ„ÄÇ

  • ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å‰∏≠Â∑≤ÁªèË∞ÉÁî®‰∫ÜËøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞Ôºö

    Ê≥®ÊÑèÂà∞ printf ÂáΩÊï∞Ë¢´Ë∞ÉÁî®„ÄÇ‰º†ÈÄíÁªô printf ÁöÑÂèÇÊï∞ÔºàargumentÔºâÊòØ 'hello, world ' „ÄÇ‰ª£Á†ÅËØ≠Âè•‰ª• ; ÁªìÂ∞æ„ÄÇ

  • Âú® C ËØ≠Ë®ÄÁºñÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÂ∏∏ËßÅÁöÑÈîôËØØÊòØÊºèÂÜôÂàÜÂè∑„ÄÇÊåâÁÖß‰ª•‰∏ãÊñπÂºè‰øÆÊîπ‰Ω†ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÔºö

    ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÂàÜÂè∑Áé∞Âú®Â∑≤Áªè‰∏çËßÅ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

  • Âú®‰Ω†ÁöÑÁªàÁ´ØÁ™óÂè£‰∏≠ÔºåËøêË°å make hello ÂëΩ‰ª§„ÄÇËøôÊó∂‰Ω†Â∞Ü‰ºöÁúãÂà∞ËÆ∏Â§öÈîôËØØ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºÅÊääÂàÜÂè∑ÊîæÂõûÊ≠£Á°ÆÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂÜçÊ¨°ËøêË°å make hello ÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÈîôËØØ‰ø°ÊÅØ‰æøÊ∂àÂ§±‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

  • ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑè‰ª£Á†Å‰∏≠ÁöÑÁâπÊÆäÁ¨¶Âè∑ „ÄÇÂ∞ùËØï‰∏Ä‰∏ãÂà†Èô§ÂÆÉÔºåÂπ∂ÈÄöËøáÊâßË°å make hello ÁîüÊàê‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇÂú®ÁªàÁ´ØÁ™óÂè£‰∏≠ËæìÂÖ• ./hello Ôºå‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫èÊúâ‰ΩïÂèòÂåñÔºü

  • Â¶Ç‰∏ãÊÅ¢Â§ç‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫èÔºö

    ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÂàÜÂè∑Âíå Â∑≤ÁªèÊÅ¢Â§ç„ÄÇ

  • ‰ª£Á†ÅÂºÄÂ§¥ÁöÑËØ≠Âè•¬†#include <stdio.h>¬†ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁâπÊÆäÁöÑÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÂÆÉÂëäËØâÁºñËØëÂô®‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®Âêç‰∏∫ stdio.h ÁöÑÂ∫ìÁöÑÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇËøôÊ†∑Ôºå‰Ω†Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî® printf ÂáΩÊï∞Á≠âËÆ∏Â§öÂÖ∂‰ªñÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÊâãÂÜåÈ°µÈù¢‰∏äÈòÖËØªËøô‰∏™Â∫ìÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÂäüËÉΩ‰ªãÁªç„ÄÇ

  • ‰∫ãÂÆû‰∏äÔºåCS50Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂ∫ìÔºåÂè´ÂÅö cs50.h „ÄÇËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨Âú®‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®Ëøô‰∏™Â∫ì„ÄÇ

Variables [ÂèòÈáè]

  • ÂõûÊÉ≥‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºåÂú®Scratch‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ËØ¢ÈóÆÁî®Êà∑ "What's your name? " Âπ∂Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂêéËØ¥Âá∫Â∏¶ÊúâÂêçÂ≠óÁöÑÈóÆÂÄô„ÄÇ

  • Âú® C ‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ËøôÊ†∑ÂÅö„ÄÇÊåâÁÖß‰ª•‰∏ãÊñπÂºè‰øÆÊîπ‰Ω†ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÔºö

    ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÂú®‰Ω†ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÈ°∂ÈÉ®Ôºå¬†#include <cs50.h> Ë¢´Âä†‰∫ÜËøõÊù•„ÄÇ‰ª£Á†Å‰∏≠¬†get_string¬†ÂáΩÊï∞Áî®‰∫é‰ªéÁî®Êà∑Ëé∑ÂèñÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÔºàstringÔºâ„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºåÂèòÈáè¬†answer¬†Ë¢´‰º†ÈÄíÁªô¬†printf¬†ÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÇ%s¬†ÂëäËØâ¬†printf¬†ÂáΩÊï∞ÂáÜÂ§áÊé•Êî∂‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤„ÄÇ

entry.title: Â§öÂÖÉÂæÆÂàÜÂ≠¶ [5]
entry.content:
ÂØπÂ∫î„ÄäÂ§ßÂ≠¶Êï∞Â≠¶ ÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ ‰∏ã„ÄãÔºö‚Äú8.5 Â§öÂÖÉÂ§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂæÆÂàÜÊ≥ï‚Äù

Êú¨ÁØáÂÜÖÂÆπ:

  • Â§öÂÖÉÂ§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÈìæÂºèÊ≥ïÂàô
  • ÈìæÂºèÁªìÊûÑ
  • ‰∏ÄÈò∂ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑ‰∏çÂèòÊÄßÂèäÂÖ∂Êé®ÂØº
  • ÈöêÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞
  • ÈöêÂáΩÊï∞Â≠òÂú®ÂÆöÁêÜ

Â§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞

1. ÈìæÂºèÊ≥ïÂàô

ÈìæÂºèÊ≥ïÂàôÊòØÁî®Êù•Ê±ÇÂ§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âü∫Êú¨Ê≥ïÂàô„ÄÇÂÆÉÂëäËØâÊàë‰ª¨ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØÁî±Âè¶Â§ñ‰∏§‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞Â§çÂêàËÄåÊàêÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÁöÑÂØºÊï∞ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáËøô‰∏§‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞Êù•ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ

ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞

ËÆæÂáΩÊï∞ f(x)f(x)f(x) Âíå g(x)g(x)g(x) ÈÉΩÂèØÂØºÔºå‰∏î y=f(g(x))y=f(g(x))y=f(g(x))ÔºåÂàô yyy ÂØπ xxx ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞‰∏∫Ôºö

dydx=dfdg‚ãÖdgdx\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}g} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}g}{\mathrm{d}x}dxdy‚Äã=dgdf‚Äã‚ãÖdxdg‚Äã

ÂØπ‰∫éÂ§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞

Âü∫Êú¨ÊÄùÊÉ≥ÊòØÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØÁî±ÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞Â§çÂêàËÄåÊàêÁöÑÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÁöÑÂØºÊï∞ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂ§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂêÑ‰∏™ÈÉ®ÂàÜÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞Áõ∏‰πòÂπ∂Áõ∏Âä†ÂæóÂà∞„ÄÇ

ÂÅáËÆæ z=f(x,y)z = f(x, y)z=f(x,y)ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ x=g(u,v)x = g(u, v)x=g(u,v)Ôºåy=h(u,v)y = h(u, v)y=h(u,v)ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊúâÔºö

‚àÇz‚àÇu=‚àÇz‚àÇx‚ãÖ‚àÇx‚àÇu+‚àÇz‚àÇy‚ãÖ‚àÇy‚àÇu\frac{\partial z}{\partial u} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{\partial x}{\partial u} + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \cdot \frac{\partial y}{\partial u}‚àÇu‚àÇz‚Äã=‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇu‚àÇx‚Äã+‚àÇy‚àÇz‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇu‚àÇy‚Äã

‚àÇz‚àÇv=‚àÇz‚àÇx‚ãÖ‚àÇx‚àÇv+‚àÇz‚àÇy‚ãÖ‚àÇy‚àÇv\frac{\partial z}{\partial v} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{\partial x}{\partial v} + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \cdot \frac{\partial y}{\partial v}‚àÇv‚àÇz‚Äã=‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇv‚àÇx‚Äã+‚àÇy‚àÇz‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àÇv‚àÇy‚Äã

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ ‚àÇz‚àÇx\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã Âíå ‚àÇz‚àÇy\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}‚àÇy‚àÇz‚Äã ÊòØ fff ÂØπ xxx Âíå yyy ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞Ôºå‚àÇx‚àÇu\frac{\partial x}{\partial u}‚àÇu‚àÇx‚Äã„ÄÅ‚àÇx‚àÇv\frac{\partial x}{\partial v}‚àÇv‚àÇx‚Äã„ÄÅ‚àÇy‚àÇu\frac{\partial y}{\partial u}‚àÇu‚àÇy‚Äã„ÄÅ‚àÇy‚àÇv\frac{\partial y}{\partial v}‚àÇv‚àÇy‚Äã ÊòØ xxx Âíå yyy ÂØπ uuu Âíå vvv ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞„ÄÇ

Ëøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÂèØ‰ª•Âæ™ÁéØÂ•óÁî®ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰∏≠Èó¥ÂèòÈáèËøòÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÂàôÁªßÁª≠‰ΩøÁî®ÈìæÂºèÊ≥ïÂàôÂç≥ÂèØ„ÄÇ

2. ÂÖ®ÂØºÊï∞

ddxF(x,f(x))=‚àÇF‚àÇx+‚àÇF‚àÇydydx=0\frac{d}{dx}F(x,f(x))=\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dx}=0dxd‚ÄãF(x,f(x))=‚àÇx‚àÇF‚Äã+‚àÇy‚àÇF‚Äãdxdy‚Äã=0

Ëß£Âá∫ dydx\frac{dy}{dx}dxdy‚Äã ÂèØÂæóÔºö

dydx=‚àí‚àÇF‚àÇx‚àÇF‚àÇy=‚àíFxFy\frac{dy}{dx}=-\frac{\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}}{\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}} = -\frac{F_x}{F_y}dxdy‚Äã=‚àí‚àÇy‚àÇF‚Äã‚àÇx‚àÇF‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíFy‚ÄãFx‚Äã‚Äã

Ëøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÂëäËØâÊàë‰ª¨ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂèØ‰ª•Â∞Ü F(x,y)=0F(x,y)=0F(x,y)=0 Áúã‰ΩúÊòØ‰ª• yyy ‰∏∫ xxx ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂØπ F(x,y)F(x,y)F(x,y) ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞Êù•Ê±ÇÂá∫Ëøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞„ÄÇ

ÈúÄË¶ÅÊ≥®ÊÑèÁöÑÊòØÔºåËøô‰∏™ÊñπÊ≥ïÂè™ÈÄÇÁî®‰∫éÊª°Ë∂≥ÈöêÂáΩÊï∞Â≠òÂú®ÂÆöÁêÜÊù°‰ª∂ÁöÑÈöêÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Âπ∂‰∏çÊòØÊâÄÊúâÁöÑÈöêÂáΩÊï∞ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•Áî®Ëøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÊ±ÇÂØº„ÄÇÂú®ÂÆûÈôÖÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÊ†πÊçÆÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÊù•Âà§Êñ≠ÊòØÂê¶ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®Ëøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèËøõË°åÊ±ÇÂØº„ÄÇ

ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏âÂèòÈáèÔºåËøáÁ®ãÊûÅÂÖ∂Áõ∏‰ººÔºå‰∏çËøáÊòØÂ§öÂ•óÁî®‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÂ±ÇÈìæÂºèÊ≥ïÂàô

‰∏âÂèòÈáè

ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏âÂÖÉÈöêÂáΩÊï∞ F(x,y,z)=0F(x,y,z)=0F(x,y,z)=0ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®Á±ª‰ººÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÊ±ÇÂÅèÂØºÊï∞„ÄÇ

ÂÅáËÆæ F(x,y,z)=0F(x,y,z)=0F(x,y,z)=0 ÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫Âá∫ zzz ‰∏∫ xxx Âíå yyy ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ z=z(x,y)z=z(x,y)z=z(x,y)ÔºåÂàôÊúâÔºö

‚àÇ‚àÇxF(x,y,z(x,y))=‚àÇF‚àÇx+‚àÇF‚àÇz‚àÇz‚àÇx=0\frac{\partial}{\partial x}F(x,y,z(x,y))=\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial F}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=0‚àÇx‚àÇ‚ÄãF(x,y,z(x,y))=‚àÇx‚àÇF‚Äã+‚àÇz‚àÇF‚Äã‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã=0

‚àÇ‚àÇyF(x,y,z(x,y))=‚àÇF‚àÇy+‚àÇF‚àÇz‚àÇz‚àÇy=0\frac{\partial}{\partial y}F(x,y,z(x,y))=\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial F}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=0‚àÇy‚àÇ‚ÄãF(x,y,z(x,y))=‚àÇy‚àÇF‚Äã+‚àÇz‚àÇF‚Äã‚àÇy‚àÇz‚Äã=0

Ëß£Âá∫ ‚àÇz‚àÇx\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã Âíå ‚àÇz‚àÇy\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}‚àÇy‚àÇz‚Äã ÂèØÂæóÔºö

‚àÇz‚àÇx=‚àí‚àÇF‚àÇx‚àÇF‚àÇz=‚àíFxFz\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=-\frac{\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}}{\frac{\partial F}{\partial z}} = -\frac{F_x}{F_z}‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã=‚àí‚àÇz‚àÇF‚Äã‚àÇx‚àÇF‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíFz‚ÄãFx‚Äã‚Äã

‚àÇz‚àÇy=‚àí‚àÇF‚àÇy‚àÇF‚àÇz=‚àíFyFz\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}=-\frac{\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}}{\frac{\partial F}{\partial z}} = -\frac{F_y}{F_z}‚àÇy‚àÇz‚Äã=‚àí‚àÇz‚àÇF‚Äã‚àÇy‚àÇF‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíFz‚ÄãFy‚Äã‚Äã

Ëøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÂëäËØâÊàë‰ª¨ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂèØ‰ª•Â∞Ü F(x,y,z)=0F(x,y,z)=0F(x,y,z)=0 Áúã‰ΩúÊòØ‰ª• zzz ‰∏∫ xxx Âíå yyy ÁöÑ‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂΩ¢ÂºèÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂØπ F(x,y,z)F(x,y,z)F(x,y,z) ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞Êù•Ê±ÇÂá∫Ëøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞„ÄÇ

ÈúÄË¶ÅÊ≥®ÊÑèÁöÑÊòØÔºå‰∏é‰∫åÂÖÉÈöêÂáΩÊï∞‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂØπ‰∫é‰∏âÂÖÉÈöêÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂêåÊó∂Ëß£Âá∫ ‚àÇz‚àÇx\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}‚àÇx‚àÇz‚Äã Âíå ‚àÇz‚àÇy\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}‚àÇy‚àÇz‚ÄãÔºåÊâçËÉΩÊ±ÇÂæó z=z(x,y)z=z(x,y)z=z(x,y) ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âºè‰πüÂè™ÈÄÇÁî®‰∫éÊª°Ë∂≥ÈöêÂáΩÊï∞Â≠òÂú®ÂÆöÁêÜÊù°‰ª∂ÁöÑÈöêÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÇ

  1. 1.Âú®Êüê‰∏™Âå∫ÂüüÂÜÖÂ§ÑÂ§Ñ‰∏ÄÈò∂ÂèØÂØºÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ ‚Ü©

entry.title: Â§öÂÖÉÂæÆÂàÜÂ≠¶ [4]
entry.content:
ÂØπÂ∫î„ÄäÂ§ßÂ≠¶Êï∞Â≠¶ ÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ ‰∏ã„ÄãÔºö‚Äú8.4 ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂèäÂÖ∂Â∫îÁî®‚Äù

Êú¨ÁØáÂÜÖÂÆπ:

  • ÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáè
  • ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜ
  • ÂèØÂæÆÔºåÂèØÂØºÂíåÂèØÂÅèÂØºÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ª

ÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáè

ÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáèÊòØÊåá‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞Âú®‰∏ÄÂÆöËåÉÂõ¥ÂÜÖÊâÄÊúâËá™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂ¢ûÈáè‰πãÂíåÔºåÂÆÉÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂæÆÂàÜÂΩ¢ÂºèÁöÑÁßØÂàÜ„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂú∞ËØ¥ÔºåËÆæ z=f(x1,x2,‚Ä¶,xn)z=f(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)z=f(x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚Äã) ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ nnn ÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú Œîx1,Œîx2,‚Ä¶,Œîxn\Delta x_1,\Delta x_2,\dots,\Delta x_nŒîx1‚Äã,Œîx2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,Œîxn‚Äã ÂàÜÂà´Ë°®Á§∫ x1,x2,‚Ä¶,xnx_1,x_2,\dots,x_nx1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚Äã ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁªÑÂ¢ûÈáèÔºåÈÇ£‰πà zzz ÁöÑÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáèÂèØ‰ª•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫Ôºö

Œîz=f(x1+Œîx1,¬†x2+Œîx2,¬†‚Ä¶,¬†xn+Œîxn)‚àíf(x1,x2,‚Ä¶,xn)\Delta z = f(x_1+\Delta x_1,\ x_2+\Delta x_2,\ \dots,\ x_n+\Delta x_n) - f(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)Œîz=f(x1‚Äã+Œîx1‚Äã,¬†x2‚Äã+Œîx2‚Äã,¬†‚Ä¶,¬†xn‚Äã+Œîxn‚Äã)‚àíf(x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚Äã)

ÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáèÂèØ‰ª•Áúã‰ΩúÊòØÂáΩÊï∞Âú®‰∏ÄÂÆöËåÉÂõ¥ÂÜÖÊâÄÊúâËá™ÂèòÈáèÂ¢ûÈáè‰πãÂíåÔºåÂÆÉÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÂæÆÂàÜÂΩ¢ÂºèÊù•Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫Ôºö

Œîz=Œîf=‚àÇf‚àÇx1Œîx1+‚àÇf‚àÇx2Œîx2+‚ãØ+‚àÇf‚àÇxnŒîxn\Delta z = \Delta f = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \Delta x_1 + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \Delta x_2 + \dots + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_n} \Delta x_nŒîz=Œîf=‚àÇx1‚Äã‚àÇf‚ÄãŒîx1‚Äã+‚àÇx2‚Äã‚àÇf‚ÄãŒîx2‚Äã+‚ãØ+‚àÇxn‚Äã‚àÇf‚ÄãŒîxn‚Äã

ËøôÈáåÁöÑ dfdfdf Ë°®Á§∫ÂáΩÊï∞ fff ÁöÑÂæÆÂàÜÂΩ¢ÂºèÔºå‰πüÁß∞ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜ„ÄÇÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáèÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÂèØ‰ª•Áúã‰ΩúÊòØÂØπÂæÆÂàÜÂΩ¢ÂºèÁöÑÁßØÂàÜÔºåÂç≥Ôºö

Œîz=‚à´PQdf\Delta z = \int_{P}^{Q} dfŒîz=‚à´PQ‚Äãdf

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ PPP Âíå QQQ ÊòØËá™ÂèòÈáè‰ªé (x1,x2,‚Ä¶,xn)(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)(x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚Äã) ÂèòÂåñÂà∞ (x1+Œîx1,x2+Œîx2,‚Ä¶,xn+Œîxn)(x_1+\Delta x_1, x_2+\Delta x_2, \dots, x_n+\Delta x_n)(x1‚Äã+Œîx1‚Äã,x2‚Äã+Œîx2‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚Äã+Œîxn‚Äã) ÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÁªèËøáÁöÑË∑ØÂæÑÔºåÁß∞‰∏∫ÁßØÂàÜË∑ØÂæÑ„ÄÇ

ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜ

1. ÂÆö‰πâ

ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂ∞±ÊòØÁªôÂ§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑÁâπÊÆäÁß∞Ë∞ì[1]„ÄÇ

ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÊòØÊåá‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÂÄºÂú®Êüê‰∏ÄÁÇπÂ§ÑÁöÑÂæÆÂ∞èÂèòÂåñÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ËØ•ÁÇπÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞Êù•ËÆ°ÁÆóÂá∫Êù•ÁöÑÂæÆÂàÜÂΩ¢Âºè„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂú∞ËØ¥ÔºåËÆæ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,¬†y)f(x,\ y)f(x,¬†y)ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÁöÑÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂèØ‰ª•Ë¢´Ë°®Á§∫‰∏∫Ôºö

df=‚àÇf‚àÇxdx+‚àÇf‚àÇydydf = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} dx + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} dydf=‚àÇx‚àÇf‚Äãdx+‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äãdy

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ dxdxdx Âíå dydydy ÂàÜÂà´Ë°®Á§∫ xxx Âíå yyy ÁöÑÂæÆÂ∞èÂèòÂåñÈáè„ÄÇ

Ëøô‰∏™ÂºèÂ≠êÂèØ‰ª•ÁêÜËß£‰∏∫ÔºåÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÊòØÁî±ÂáΩÊï∞Âú® xxx ÊñπÂêëÂíå yyy ÊñπÂêë‰∏äÁöÑÂæÆÂ∞èÂèòÂåñÈáèÂä†ÊùÉÂæóÂà∞ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

Á®çÂä†ËßÇÂØüÊàë‰ª¨ËÉΩÂèëÁé∞ÂáΩÊï∞ fff Âú®ÁÇπ (x0,¬†y0)(x_0,\ y_0)(x0‚Äã,¬†y0‚Äã) ÁöÑÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂ∞±ÊòØ Œîf\Delta fŒîf ÂØπ‰∫é Œîx\Delta xŒîx Âíå Œîy\Delta yŒîy ÁöÑÁ∫øÊÄßËøë‰ºº[2]

ÈúÄË¶ÅÊ≥®ÊÑèÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂè™ÊúâÊâÄÊúâÂÅèÂØºÊï∞ÈÉΩËøûÁª≠ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÔºàÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•Âå∫Èó¥ÂÜÖËøûÁª≠ÂèØÂæÆÔºâÊâçËÉΩÊúâÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÔºåÂê¶ÂàôÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜ‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®„ÄÇËøôÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂ∞±ÊòØÂ§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÂèØÂæÆÔºåÂèØÂØºÂíåÂèØÂÅèÂØºÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ªÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Âú®Êé•‰∏ãÊù•Êõ¥ÊúâÊù°ÁêÜÁöÑÂèôËø∞ËøôÁÇπ„ÄÇ

2. ÂèØÂæÆÔºåÂèØÂØºÂíåÂèØÂÅèÂØºÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ª

ÈíàÂØπÁÇπ

  • ÂèØÂæÆ ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂèØÂØº

Âõ†‰∏∫ÂØºÊï∞Â∞±ÊòØÂ¢ûÈáèÈô§‰ª•ÂæÆÂàÜÔºõÂ¢ûÈáèÂøÖÂÆöËÉΩÂ≠òÂú®ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Âè™Ë¶ÅÂæÆÂàÜÂ≠òÂú®ÔºåÂØºÊï∞Â∞±Â≠òÂú®

  • ÂèØÂÅèÂØº ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂèØÂæÆ

ÂØπ‰∫éÊØè‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÈÉΩÊòØÂèØÂÅèÂØºÁöÑÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊ†πÊçÆÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑÂÆö‰πâÔºåÊ≠§Êó∂ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂ≠òÂú®

  • ÊÄªÁªìÔºöÂèØÂÅèÂØº ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂèØÂæÆ ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂèØÂØº

ÈíàÂØπÂüü

  • ÂùáÂèØÂæÆ ‚ü∂\longrightarrow‚ü∂ ÂáΩÊï∞ËøûÁª≠

Âè™ÊúâËøûÁª≠ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÊâçËÉΩÂÅöÂà∞ÂùáÂèØÂæÆ

  • ÂØºÊï∞ËøûÁª≠ ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂùáÂèØÂæÆ

ÂùáËøûÁª≠Â∞±ÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÂú®Ëøô‰∏™Âüü‰∏≠ÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÊòØÂèØÂØºÁöÑÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÊòØÂèØÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑ

  • ÂÅèÂØºÊï∞ÂùáËøûÁª≠ ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂùáÂèØÂæÆ

ÂùáËøûÁª≠Â∞±ÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÂú®Ëøô‰∏™Âüü‰∏≠ÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÊòØÂèØÂÅèÂØºÁöÑÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÊòØÂèØÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑ

  • ÊÄªÁªìÔºö ÂÅèÂØºÊï∞ÂùáËøûÁª≠ ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂØºÊï∞ËøûÁª≠ ‚ü∑\longleftrightarrow‚ü∑ ÂùáÂèØÂæÆ ‚ü∂\longrightarrow‚ü∂ ÂáΩÊï∞ËøûÁª≠

3. ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑÂá†‰ΩïÊÑè‰πâ

Ê≠£Â¶ÇÂâçÊñáÊâÄËØ¥ÔºåÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÊòØÂÖ®Â¢ûÈáèÂÖ≥‰∫é‰∏§‰∏™Ëá™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÁ∫øÊÄßËøë‰ººÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Êàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÂæóÂà∞ÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑËøë‰ººËÆ°ÁÆóÂÖ¨Âºè„ÄÇ

ÂÅáËÆæÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,¬†y)f(x,\ y)f(x,¬†y)ÔºåÂπ∂‰∏î f(x,¬†y)f(x,\ y)f(x,¬†y) Âú®Êüê‰∏ÄÁÇπ (x0,¬†y0)(x_0,\ y_0)(x0‚Äã,¬†y0‚Äã) Â§ÑËøûÁª≠ÂèØÂæÆÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÂú®ËØ•ÁÇπÁöÑÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂèØ‰ª•Ëøë‰ººË°®Á§∫‰∏∫Ôºö

df=‚àÇf‚àÇx(x0,¬†y0)Œîx+‚àÇf‚àÇy(x0,¬†y0)Œîydf = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x_0,\ y_0) \Delta x + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x_0,\ y_0) \Delta ydf=‚àÇx‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,¬†y0‚Äã)Œîx+‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äã(x0‚Äã,¬†y0‚Äã)Œîy

ÈúÄË¶ÅÊ≥®ÊÑèÁöÑÊòØÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÂè™ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëøë‰ººÂÄºÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂè™Âú® (x0,¬†y0)(x_0,\ y_0)(x0‚Äã,¬†y0‚Äã) ÁÇπÈôÑËøëÊúâÊïà„ÄÇÂΩìÂ¢ûÈáè Œîx\Delta xŒîx Âíå Œîy\Delta yŒîy ÂæàÂ∞èÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÁöÑËØØÂ∑ÆÂèØ‰ª•ÂøΩÁï•‰∏çËÆ°ÔºõÂõ†Ê≠§Ë¶ÅÊØîËæÉÂáÜÁ°ÆÂú∞ËÆ°ÁÆóÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÔºåÈúÄË¶Å‰ª§ Œîx\Delta xŒîx Âíå Œîy\Delta yŒîy Ë∂ãËøë‰∫éÈõ∂„ÄÇ

Ê†πÊçÆËøô‰∏™ÂÖ¨ÂºèÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•Á™•ËßÅÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑÂá†‰ΩïÊÑè‰πâÔºöÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÁöÑÂá†‰ΩïÊÑè‰πâÊòØÂæÆÂ∞èÁöÑÂπ≥Èù¢Âå∫ÂüüÔºåÂç≥ÂæÆÂÖÉ„ÄÇ

Êàë‰ª¨Êù•Êé®Êºî‰∏Ä‰∏ãÂÖ∂Áî±Êù•Ôºö

ÂØπ‰∫é‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,¬†y)f(x,\ y)f(x,¬†y)ÔºåÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜ dfdfdf ÁöÑÂêëÈáè(dx,¬†dy)(dx,\ dy)(dx,¬†dy)Âú®ÁÇπ (x,¬†y)(x,\ y)(x,¬†y) ÈôÑËøëÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂÅöÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âπ≥Èù¢ÁöÑÊ≥ïÂêëÈáèÔºåËØ•Âπ≥Èù¢ÊòØÈÄöËøáÁÇπ (x,¬†y,f(x,y))(x,\ y,f(x,y))(x,¬†y,f(x,y)) ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞Êõ≤Èù¢ÁöÑÂàáÂπ≥Èù¢„ÄÇËøô‰∏™ÂàáÂπ≥Èù¢ÊèèËø∞‰∫ÜÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÁÇπÁöÑÂ±ÄÈÉ®ÂèòÂåñÁéá„ÄÇ

ÂØπ‰∫éÂæÆÂ∞èÂ¢ûÈáè (dx,¬†dy)(dx,\ dy)(dx,¬†dy)Ôºådfdfdf Á≠â‰∫éÂàáÂπ≥Èù¢ÁöÑÊ≥ïÂêëÈáè‰∏éÂ¢ûÈáèÁöÑÁÇπÁßØÔºåÂç≥Ôºö

df=‚àáf‚ãÖdr=‚àÇf‚àÇxdx+‚àÇf‚àÇydydf = \nabla f \cdot d\mathbf{r} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}dx + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}dydf=‚àáf‚ãÖdr=‚àÇx‚àÇf‚Äãdx+‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äãdy

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Ôºå‚àáf\nabla f‚àáf ÊòØÂáΩÊï∞ fff ÁöÑÊ¢ØÂ∫¶ÔºåÂç≥ (‚àÇf‚àÇx,¬†‚àÇf‚àÇy)(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x},\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial y})(‚àÇx‚àÇf‚Äã,¬†‚àÇy‚àÇf‚Äã)Ôºådrd\mathbf{r}dr ÊòØÂæÆÂ∞èÂ¢ûÈáè (dx,¬†dy)(dx,\ dy)(dx,¬†dy) ÁöÑÂêëÈáèÂΩ¢Âºè„ÄÇËøô‰∏™ÂºèÂ≠êÂèØ‰ª•Ëß£Èáä‰∏∫ÔºöÂΩì (dx,¬†dy)(dx,\ dy)(dx,¬†dy) Â¢ûÂä†Êó∂ÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ÂÄºÁöÑÂèòÂåñÁéáÁ≠â‰∫éÂàáÂπ≥Èù¢Ê≥ïÂêëÈáè‰∏éÂ¢ûÈáèÂêëÈáèÁöÑÁÇπÁßØ„ÄÇ

‰ªéÂá†‰Ωï‰∏äÊù•ÁúãÔºåÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂÅöÊòØÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,¬†y)f(x,\ y)f(x,¬†y) Âú® (x,¬†y)(x,\ y)(x,¬†y) ÁÇπÈôÑËøëÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂæÆÂ∞èÂπ≥Èù¢Âå∫ÂüüÁöÑÂàáÂπ≥Èù¢ÁöÑÊ≥ïÂêëÈáè‰πò‰ª•ÂæÆÂ∞èÂ¢ûÈáèÁöÑÂÜÖÁßØ„ÄÇ‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËØ¥ÔºåÂÖ®ÂæÆÂàÜ df(x,¬†y)df(x,\ y)df(x,¬†y) Ë°®Á§∫ÁöÑÊòØÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,¬†y)f(x,\ y)f(x,¬†y) Âú®ÁÇπ (x,¬†y)(x,\ y)(x,¬†y) Â§ÑÊ≤øÁùÄÂæÆÂ∞èÂπ≥Èù¢Âå∫ÂüüÁöÑÊñπÂêëÁöÑÂæÆÂ∞èÂèòÂåñÁéá„ÄÇ

  1. 1.ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂæÆÂàÜÊàë‰ª¨Áõ¥Êé•Áß∞‰∏∫ÂæÆÂàÜ ‚Ü©

entry.title: ÁªèÂØº[3]ÔºöÁªèÊµé‰ΩìÁ≥ª
entry.content:

III. Ê∑∑ÂêàÁªèÊµé

ÁªùÂ§ßÂ§öÊï∞Áé∞‰ª£ÁªèÊµé‰ΩìÁ≥ªÈÉΩÊòØÊ∑∑ÂêàÁªèÊµéÔºå‰ªã‰∫éËÆ°ÂàíÁªèÊµéÂíåÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁªèÊµé‰πãÈó¥ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Á∫ØÁ≤πÁöÑËÆ°ÂàíÁªèÊµéËøá‰∫éËøüÈíùÔºåËÄåÂ≠òÁ≤πÁöÑÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁªèÊµéÈöæÈÄÉÂ∏ÇÂú∫Â§±ÁÅµ[1]„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºö

II. Âæ™ÁéØÊµÅÂä®Âõæ

ÊîøÂ∫úÂú®Âæ™ÁéØ‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®

ÊîøÂ∫úÂêåÊ†∑‰ºöË¥≠‰π∞‰∫ßÂìÅÂíåËµÑÊ∫êÔºå‰∏∫ÂÖ¨ÂÖ±ÊúçÂä°ÔºåÂü∫Á°ÄÂª∫ËÆæÔºå‰∏™‰ΩìË°•Ë¥¥‰ªòÈí±ÔºåËÄåÈÄöËøáÁ®éÊî∂ÂíåË¥∑Ê¨æÊù•Ëé∑ÂæóÊî∂ÂÖ•„ÄÇ

entry.title: ÁªèÂØº[2]Ôºö‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñÂíåË¥∏Êòì
entry.content:
‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñ

Â§ö‰∏™‰∫∫ËÅöÂú®‰∏ÄËµ∑Â∑•‰ΩúÔºåÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫Âè™Ë¥üË¥£ÂÅöÂÖ∂ÊúÄÊìÖÈïøÁöÑÈÉ®ÂàÜ„ÄÇ

I. Â∑•‰∏öÈù©ÂëΩ

Âú®ÁªüËÆ°Â≠¶ÊÑè‰πâ[1]‰∏äÔºåÂ∑•‰∏öÈù©ÂëΩ‰ª•ÂâçÔºå‰∫∫‰ª¨ÁöÑÁîüÊ¥ªÈÉΩÈùûÂ∏∏ÁöÑÊÇ≤ÊÉ®„ÄÇËÄåÂú®Â∑•‰∏öÈù©ÂëΩ‰πãÂêéÔºå‰∫∫ÂùáÂØøÂëΩÔºåÈ£üÁâ©‰æõÁªôÔºåÂåªÁñóËÆæÊñΩÂ§ßÂπÖÊèêÂçá„ÄÇ

II. ‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñÁöÑÂèëÂ±ï

Â∞ΩÁÆ°Âú®Â∑•‰∏öÈù©ÂëΩ‰ª•ÂâçÔºåÁ§æ‰ºö‰∏äÂ∑≤ÁªèÂ≠òÂú®‰∏ÄÂÆöÁöÑ‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñÁé∞Ë±°Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØ‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñÁ®ãÂ∫¶ÈùûÂ∏∏‰Ωé„ÄÇËÄåÂú®Â∑•‰∏öÈù©ÂëΩ‰πãÂêéÔºåÁ§æ‰ºöÁîü‰∫ß‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñÁ®ãÂ∫¶ÂâçÊâÄÊú™ÊúâÂú∞ÂçáÈ´ò„ÄÇÂèØ‰ª•ÊÉ≥‰∏ÄÊÉ≥Ôºå‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÊâãÊú∫ÁöÑÂà∂ÈÄ†ÈúÄË¶ÅÂ§öÂ∞ëÊù•Ëá™‰∏çÂêå‰∏ì‰∏öÈ¢ÜÂüüÁöÑ‰∏ìÂÆ∂ÊâçËÉΩÂÆûÁé∞„ÄÇ‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñ‰∏çÊòØÂçïÁ∫ØÂú∞ÊèêÈ´òÁîü‰∫ßÊïàÁéáÔºàÊ∏∏ÊàèËßíËâ≤ÁªèÈ™åÂ¢ûÂä†ÔºâÔºåÊõ¥ÊòØËÆ©Áîü‰∫ßÊïàÁéáÁ™ÅÁ†¥‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÁßçÁì∂È¢àÔºåÂÆåÊàê‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Ë∑®Ë∂ä„ÄÇÔºàÊ∏∏ÊàèËßíËâ≤Á≠âÁ∫ßÂ¢ûÂä†Ôºâ

Ë¥∏Êòì

ÊØè‰∏™‰∏™‰ΩìÂè™Ë¥üË¥£Áîü‰∫ßÂÖ∂ÊúÄÊìÖÈïøÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅÔºõÁÑ∂ÂêéÁî®Ëøô‰∏™ÂïÜÂìÅÂéª‰∫§Êç¢Âà´ÁöÑ‰∏™‰ΩìÁîü‰∫ßÁöÑÔºåÂÖ∂ÊúÄÊìÖÈïøÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅ„ÄÇ

I. Áîü‰∫ßÂèØËÉΩÊÄßËæπÁïåÔºàPPFÔºâ

‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñ‰∏éË¥∏Êòì_ÂìîÂì©ÂìîÂì©_bilibili ÁöÑ3:40Â§ÑÊúâËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ªãÁªç„ÄÇÂú®‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÁ¨îËÆ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Âè™ËÆ®ËÆ∫ÂåÖÂê´‰∏§‰∏™ÂïÜÂìÅÁöÑÁÆÄÂçïÊ®°Âûã„ÄÇ

Áîü‰∫ßÁä∂ÊÄÅ

  • ‰ΩéÊïàÁîü‰∫ß

ÂΩì‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏™‰ΩìÁîü‰∫ßÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅÊï∞ÈáèËêΩÂú® PPF ‰ª•ÂÜÖÊó∂ÔºåËØ¥ÊòéÂÖ∂ÂØπËµÑÊ∫êÁöÑÂà©Áî®ÊïàÁéáÊ≤°ÊúâËææÂà∞ÊúÄÈ´òÔºåÁªüÁß∞‰∏∫‰ΩéÊïàÁîü‰∫ß

  • È´òÊïàÁîü‰∫ß

ÂΩì‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏™‰ΩìÁîü‰∫ßÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅÊï∞ÈáèÂàöÂ•ΩËêΩÂú® PPF ‰πã‰∏äÊó∂ÔºåËØ¥ÊòéÂÖ∂ÂØπËµÑÊ∫êÁöÑÂà©Áî®ÊïàÁéáËææÂà∞ÊúÄÈ´òÔºåÁß∞‰∏∫È´òÊïàÊïàÁîü‰∫ß

‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏™‰ΩìÁîü‰∫ßÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅÊï∞ÈáèÊòØ‰∏çÂèØËÉΩËêΩÂú® PPF ‰ª•Â§ñÁöÑÔºåËøô‰∫õÁîü‰∫ßÂèØ‰ª•Ë¢´Áß∞‰Ωú‰∏çÂèØËÉΩÁîü‰∫ß

ÁªùÂØπ‰ºòÂäø

ÂèåÊñπÂêåÊó∂Âè™Áîü‰∫ß‰∏ÄÁßçÂïÜÂìÅÊó∂ÔºåËÉΩÁîü‰∫ßÊõ¥Â§öÂïÜÂìÅÁöÑ‰∏ÄÊñπÔºåÊúâÁùÄÁîü‰∫ßËøôÁßçÂïÜÂìÅÁöÑÁªùÂØπ‰ºòÂäø„ÄÇ

Áõ∏ÂØπ‰ºòÂäø

ÂèåÊñπÁîü‰∫ß‰∏ÄÁßç‰∫ßÂìÅÊó∂ÔºåÊú∫‰ºöÊàêÊú¨Êõ¥‰ΩéÁöÑ‰∏ÄÊñπÔºåÊúâÁùÄÁîü‰∫ßËøôÁßç‰∫ßÂìÅÁöÑÁõ∏ÂØπ‰ºòÂäø„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºö ÂÅáËÆæÁæéÂõΩÂ§öÁîü‰∫ß‰∏ÄÊû∂È£ûÊú∫ÔºåÂ∞±Ë¶ÅÂ∞ëÁîü‰∫ß4Âê®ÈûãÔºàÊú∫‰ºöÊàêÊú¨ÔºâÔºåËÄå‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ§öÁîü‰∫ß‰∏ÄÊû∂È£ûÊú∫ÔºåÂ∞±Ë¶ÅÂ∞ëÁîü‰∫ß8Âê®ÈûãÔºàÊú∫‰ºöÊàêÊú¨ÔºâÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÁæéÂõΩÊã•ÊúâÁîü‰∫ßÈ£ûÊú∫ÁöÑÁõ∏ÂØπ‰ºòÂäøÔºõ‰∏çËøáÂèçËøáÊù•Ôºå‰∏≠ÂõΩÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂ∞±Êã•Êúâ‰∫ÜÁîü‰∫ßÈûãÂ≠êÁöÑÁõ∏ÂØπ‰ºòÂäø

ÈÄöËøáËøô‰∏™Ê®°ÂûãÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÂæóÁü•ÁêÜÊÉ≥ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÁöÑË¥∏ÊòìÈÉΩÊòØÂèåËµ¢ÔºåÂ±û‰∫éÊ≠£ÂíåÂçöÂºà„ÄÇÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂéüÁêÜÊòØÊØè‰∏™‰∏™‰ΩìÁîü‰∫ßÂïÜÂìÅÁöÑÊú∫‰ºöÊàêÊú¨ÔºàÁõ∏ÂØπ‰ºòÂäøÔºâ‰∏çÂêå„ÄÇ

  1. 1.‰∫∫ÂùáÂØøÂëΩÔºå‰∫∫ÂùáÊî∂ÂÖ•ÔºåÂÑøÁ´•Ê≠ª‰∫°ÁéáÁ≠â ‚Ü©

entry.title: ÁªèÂØº[1]ÔºöÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÊÄªËßà
entry.content:
‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶

ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶‰∏çÊòØÁ†îÁ©∂ÈáëÈí±ÂíåËá¥ÂØåÁöÑÁßëÂ≠¶ÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂Ëøô‰∫õÊòØÈáëËûçÂ≠¶ÁöÑ‰ªªÂä°Ôºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÊäïËµÑÁöÑÁßëÂ≠¶„ÄÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÊòØÁ†îÁ©∂ËµÑÊ∫êÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂàÜÈÖçÂíåÂà©Áî®ÁöÑÁßëÂ≠¶ÔºåÂíå‰∫∫‰∏éÂÜ≥Á≠ñÊúÄÁõ∏ÂÖ≥„ÄÇÂú®ÂæÆËßÇÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÂÆÉÁ†îÁ©∂‰∫∫‰ª¨Â¶Ç‰ΩïÊùÉË°°ÁöÑÊàêÊú¨ÂíåÊî∂ÁõäÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏™‰∫∫Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂàÜÈÖçÂíåÂà©Áî®ËµÑÊ∫êÔºõÂú®Êõ¥ÂÆèËßÇÁöÑÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÂÆÉÁ†îÁ©∂ÂõΩÂÆ∂Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂà∂ÂÆöÁªèÊµéÊîøÁ≠ñÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÁ§æ‰ºöÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂàÜÈÖçÂíåÂà©Áî®ËµÑÊ∫ê„ÄÇ

ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÂÅáËÆæ

  • ËµÑÊ∫êÁ®ÄÁº∫

‰∫∫‰ª¨Êã•ÊúâÊó†Á©∑ÁöÑÊ¨≤ÊúõÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØËµÑÊ∫êÊòØÊúâÈôêÁöÑ

  • Êú∫‰ºöÊàêÊú¨

ÊØè‰∏Ä‰ª∂‰∫ãÊÉÖ (everything) ÈÉΩÊòØÊúâÊàêÊú¨ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

Âç≥‰Ωø‰∏Ä‰∫õÁúãËµ∑Êù•Ê≤°ÊúâÊàêÊú¨ÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖÂÖ∂ÂÆû‰πü‰ºöÊúâÊàêÊú¨ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊó∂Èó¥ÊàêÊú¨„ÄÇ

  • ÁêÜÊÄßË°å‰∏∫

‰∏™‰∫∫ÂíåÊú∫ÊûÑÊòØÁêÜÊÄßÁöÑ„ÄÅÊòéÊô∫ÁöÑÂÜ≥Á≠ñËÄÖ[1]Ôºå‰ªñ‰ª¨Â∞ÜÊùÉË°°ÂêÑÁßçÊàêÊú¨ÂíåÊî∂ÁõäÔºå‰ª•ÂÅöÂá∫ÊúÄ‰ºòÂÜ≥Á≠ñ„ÄÇ

  1. ‰∫∫‰ª¨Âú®ÂÅöÂÜ≥Á≠ñÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÈù¢‰∏¥ÊùÉË°°ÂèñËàç
  2. ÂæóÂà∞ÊüêÊ†∑‰∏úË•øÁöÑÊàêÊú¨ÊòØ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÂæóÂà∞ÂÆÉÊâÄÊîæÂºÉÁöÑ‰∏úË•øÁöÑ‰ª∑ÂÄº
  3. ËÄÉËôëËæπÈôÖÈáè[2]
  4. ‰∫∫‰ª¨‰ºöÂØπÊøÄÂä±[3]ÂÅöÂá∫ÂèçÂ∫î

ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÁöÑ‰∏ªË¶ÅÂàÜÊîØ

  • ÂæÆËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶

ÂæÆËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂÖ≥Ê≥®‰∏™‰Ωì„ÄÅÂÆ∂Â∫≠Âíå‰ºÅ‰∏öÁ≠âÂ∞èÂûãÁªèÊµéÂçï‰ΩçÁöÑË°å‰∏∫ÂíåÂÜ≥Á≠ñÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂‰∏™‰ΩìÂú®Â∏ÇÂú∫‰∏äÁöÑ‰∫§Êç¢Ë°å‰∏∫ÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ª∑Ê†º„ÄÅÊ∂àË¥πËÄÖË°å‰∏∫„ÄÅÁîü‰∫ßËÄÖË°å‰∏∫„ÄÅÂ∏ÇÂú∫Á´û‰∫âÁ≠âÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇÂæÆËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶Á†îÁ©∂ÁöÑÊòØÁªèÊµé‰Ωì‰∏≠ÁöÑÂ∞èÈÉ®ÂàÜÔºåÂº∫Ë∞ÉÂàÜÊûê‰æõÊ±ÇÂÖ≥Á≥ªÂíåËµÑÊ∫êÂàÜÈÖçÔºå‰ªéËÄåÊè≠Á§∫ÁªèÊµé‰Ωì‰∏≠ÂÜ≥Á≠ñËÄÖÁöÑË°å‰∏∫Ê®°Âºè„ÄÅÁªèÊµéÊú∫Âà∂ÁöÑËøêË°åËßÑÂæã„ÄÇ

  • ÂÆèËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶

ÂÆèËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂàôÂÖ≥Ê≥®Êï¥‰∏™ÁªèÊµé‰ΩìÁ≥ªÁöÑÊÄª‰ΩìËøêË°åÊÉÖÂÜµÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂ÊÄª‰ΩìÁªèÊµéÂ¢ûÈïø„ÄÅÈÄöË¥ßËÜ®ËÉÄ„ÄÅÂ§±‰∏öÁéá„ÄÅË¥ßÂ∏ÅÊîøÁ≠ñÁ≠âÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇÂÆÉÁ†îÁ©∂ÁöÑÊòØÁªèÊµé‰Ωì‰∏≠ÁöÑÊï¥‰ΩìÔºå‰∏ªË¶ÅËÄÉËôëÁªèÊµé‰ΩìÁöÑÂÆèËßÇËøêË°åÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÅÁªèÊµé‰Ωì‰∏≠ÁöÑÊîøÁ≠ñÂíåÊú∫Âà∂Á≠â„ÄÇ

Á±ªÊØî

  • Â¶ÇÊûúÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÊòØÁîüÁâ©Â≠¶ÔºöÂÆèËßÇÁªèÊµé -> ÁîüÊÄÅÂ≠¶ÔºõÂæÆËßÇÁªèÊµé -> ÁªÜËÉûÁîüÁâ©Â≠¶
  • Â¶ÇÊûúÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÊòØÁâ©ÁêÜÂ≠¶ÔºöÂÆèËßÇÁªèÊµé -> ÂÆáÂÆôÂ≠¶„ÄÅÁõ∏ÂØπËÆ∫ÔºõÂæÆËßÇÁªèÊµé -> ÁâõÈ°øÂäõÂ≠¶

ÊÄªÁöÑÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂæÆËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÁöÑÊòØÂ∞èÂûãÁªèÊµéÂçï‰ΩçÁöÑË°å‰∏∫ÂíåÂÜ≥Á≠ñÔºåËÄåÂÆèËßÇÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÁöÑÊòØÊï¥‰∏™ÁªèÊµé‰ΩìÁ≥ªÁöÑÊÄª‰ΩìËøêË°åÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÇ

ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÁöÑË°®Ëø∞Â∑•ÂÖ∑

  • ÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞ÔºàPositive StatementÔºâ

ÊòØÊåáÊèèËø∞Áé∞ÂÆûÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÅÂØπ‰∫ãÂÆûÁöÑÈôàËø∞ÊàñËß£ÈáäÔºåÂÆÉÊòØÂèØ‰ª•Ë¢´È™åËØÅÁöÑ„ÄÅÂÆ¢ËßÇÁöÑÈôàËø∞„ÄÇÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞Âπ∂‰∏çÂåÖÂê´>‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏ªËßÇÁöÑÊÑèËßÅ„ÄÅ‰ª∑ÂÄºËßÇÊàñÂª∫ËÆÆÔºåÂÆÉ‰ªÖ‰ªÖÊòØÂØπ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁªèÊµéÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÊèèËø∞ÂíåËß£Èáä„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå‚ÄùÂ∑•ËµÑ‰∏äÂçáÂØºËá¥‰ºÅ‰∏öÊàêÊú¨‰∏äÂçáÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞ ‚ÄúÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉ‰ªÖ‰ªÖÊòØÂØπÂ∑•ËµÑÂíå‰ºÅ‰∏öÊàêÊú¨‰πãÈó¥ÂÖ≥Á≥ªÁöÑÊèèËø∞ÂíåËß£Èáä„ÄÇ

  • ËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞ÔºàNormative StatementÔºâ

ÂàôÊòØÊåáÂê´Êúâ‰∏ªËßÇÂà§Êñ≠„ÄÅ‰ª∑ÂÄºËßÇÊàñÂª∫ËÆÆÁöÑÈôàËø∞ÔºåÂÆÉ‰ª¨Ê∂âÂèä‰∫∫‰ª¨Â∫îËØ•Â¶Ç‰ΩïË°åÂä®ÊàñÂÅöÂá∫ÂÜ≥Á≠ñ„ÄÇËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞ÊòØÂü∫‰∫é‰∫∫‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰ª∑ÂÄºËßÇÂíå‰ø°ÂøµÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§ÂÆÉ‰ª¨‰∏çËÉΩË¢´ËØÅÊòéÊàñËØÅ‰º™„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå‚Äú‰ºÅ‰∏öÂ∫îËØ•‰∏∫ÂëòÂ∑•Êèê‰æõÊõ¥È´òÁöÑËñ™ËµÑ ‚ÄùÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉÂåÖÂê´‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏ªËßÇÁöÑ‰ª∑ÂÄºÂà§Êñ≠ÔºåÂç≥‰ºÅ‰∏öÂ∫îËØ•ÊÄéÊ†∑ÂØπÂæÖÂëòÂ∑•„ÄÇ

Âú®ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶‰∏≠ÔºåÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞ÂíåËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞ÁöÑÂå∫ÂàÜÈùûÂ∏∏ÈáçË¶Å„ÄÇ

ÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞ÂèØ‰ª•‰∏∫ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂÆ∂Êèê‰æõÂÖ≥‰∫éÁªèÊµéÁé∞Ë±°ÁöÑÂÆ¢ËßÇÊèèËø∞ÂíåÂàÜÊûêÔºåËÄåËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞ÂàôÂèçÊò†‰∫Ü‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂØπ‰∫éÁªèÊµéÁé∞Ë±°ÁöÑ‰∏ªËßÇÁúãÊ≥ïÂíåÊÄÅÂ∫¶„ÄÇÔºàËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞Ôºâ

ÁªèÊµéÂ≠¶ÂÆ∂Â∫îËØ•Âä™Âäõ‰øùÊåÅÂÆ¢ËßÇ„ÄÅÁêÜÊÄßÁöÑÊÄÅÂ∫¶ÔºåÂ∞ΩÂèØËÉΩÂú∞Â∞ÜËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞ËΩ¨Âåñ‰∏∫ÂÆûËØÅË°®Ëø∞Ôºå‰ª•‰æøËøõË°åÂÆ¢ËßÇÁöÑÁªèÊµéÂàÜÊûêÂíåÂÜ≥Á≠ñÂà∂ÂÆö„ÄÇÔºàËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËßÑËåÉË°®Ëø∞Ôºâ

entry.title: CS100 Homework [1]
entry.content:
Problems:

  1. Find Bugs!
  2. Equation of A Line
  3. Spell It Out

CS100 Homework 1 (Spring 2023)

Deadline: 2023-02-26 (Sun) 23:59:59

Late submission will open for 24 hours after the deadline, with 50% point deduction.

If you get full marks in this assignment by no more than 20 submission attempts, you can earn
special OJ displays and a "1-case protection" that can be used in further assignments to cancel
one testcase failure. See Piazza or OJ dashboard for more information.

Problem 1: Find Bugs!

Description

Your friend has just started learning programming, and has spent hours on a textbook practice
problem. He/She asks you for help by treating you to a KFC Crazy Thursday meal. You agree, and
he/she sends you a .txt file:

For the sake of Crazy Thursday, you now have the responsibility to debug your friend's code
(Don't do so in ShanghaiTech!). You may first fix compile errors so that the code runs, and then
figure out why it (possibly) does not produce correct results.

Input format

The first line contains a number , representing the number of students in a class.

The following lines each contain , score of a student.

  • For 100% cases, 0<n‚©Ω500 < n \leqslant 500<n‚©Ω50, and 0<si‚©Ω1000 < s_i \leqslant 1000<si‚Äã‚©Ω100.

Output format

Four sentences, specified as in printf statements in the code.

In the last sentence, format the average score to 2 decimal digits.

Example

Input:

Output:

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Problem 2: Equation of A Line

Description

Input two points' coordinates (x,¬†y)(x,\ y)(x,¬†y) , where xxx and yyy are two integers. You need to calculate the
equation of the line going through these two points in the form of y=kx+by = kx + by=kx+b, or x=cx = cx=c (when
the slope k doesn't exist).

Input format

Two lines, each containing a coordinate in the form (x, y) , where x and y are integers.

  • For 100% cases, ‚à£x‚à£<1000|x| < 1000‚à£x‚à£<1000, and ‚à£y‚à£<1000|y| < 1000‚à£y‚à£<1000.

Output format

A line in the form of y = kx [+/-] b , or x = c .

  • k , b and c should all be of type double . When printed, format them to 2 decimal digits.
    If b < 0 , the minus sign - should take place of the + , turning the result into y = kx - b .

  • You do not need to simplify the cases b=0b= 0b=0, k=0k=0k=0, and k=¬±1k = \pm 1k=¬±1 . Just leave the number
    there, like y = 1.00x + 0.00.

Pay attention to spaces before and after '=' and '+'/'-' . It's safest to directly copy-paste the
above equations into your code.

Example

Input:

Output:

Input:

Output:

Input:

Output:

Input:

Output:

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Problem 3: Spell It Out

Description

"How I wish that numbers could be gone!", cursed you after a terrible math exam. That exact
night, you had a bad dream where all numbers have disappeared! No one understands 1, 2, 3,
and you had to spell them out in English like one, two, three!

Luckily you had a computer to do all this, and a piece of guide to follow:

  • Use a hyphen ('-') to connect a word ending in -ty to another word. (22 -> twenty-two, 48000 -> forty-eight thousand)

  • There is NO "-s" (plural) for words "hundred" and "thousand". Also, 100 and 1000 are spelled "one hundred" and "one thousand".

  • To use or to not use an "and" after "hundred" is both OK. However, inserting an "and" makes the spelling easier to read, so let's put an "and" after "hundred" or "thousand" when they are followed by a part less than 100. (101 -> one hundred and one, 2023 -> two thousand and twenty-three, 114500 -> one hundred and fourteen thousand five hundred)

  • NO comma (',') after the world "thousand", although it sounds more natural to stop there when reading numbers out.

  • Pay attention to spellings, especially for "fourteen", "forty", "nineteen", and "ninety"! You don't want to spend hours debugging to find out nothing but a typo!

Input description

The input is a number.

  • For 20% cases, 0‚©Ωx‚©Ω9990 \leqslant x \leqslant 9990‚©Ωx‚©Ω999 .
  • For 20% cases, x % 1000 == 0 .
  • For 100% cases, 0‚©Ωx‚©Ω9999990 \leqslant x \leqslant 9999990‚©Ωx‚©Ω999999 .

Output description

You should output the English spelling of number x in one line. It's OK whether you end the line
with a '\n' or not.

Hints

  • This problem does NOT involve strings (something we haven't learned)! Try to separate the output into different parts, and print each one with a printf! Keep in mind that printf does not necessarily end with a '\n' .

  • Some work might need to be performed multiple times (like translating 1-9 into "one" through "nine"). Why not write them into functions to make things easy and avoid bugs?

Sample input/outputs

InputOutput
0zero
44forty-four
1590one thousand five hundred and ninety
114500one hundred and fourteen thousand five hundred

Appendix: Numbers in English

0123456789
zeroonetwothreefourfivesixseveneightnine
10111213141516171819
teneleventwelvethirteenfourteenfifteensixteenseventeeneighteennineteen
20304050607080901001000
twentythirtyfortyfiftysixtyseventyeightyninetyhundredthousand

Test cases

üëâ Go to GitHub

Reference solutions

Remember, you should always solve all the problems yourself and passed all the testcases first.

  1. Find Bugs!
  2. Equation of A Line
  3. Spell It Out

entry.title: CS100 Homework [0]
entry.content:
Important message on plagiarism

The single most important point for you to realize before the beginning of your studies at ShanghaiTech is the meaning of "plagiarism":

Plagiarism is the practice of taking someone else's work or ideas and passing them off as one's own. It is the misrepresentation of the work of another as your own. It is academic theft; a serious infraction of a University honor code, and the latter is your responsibility to uphold. Instances of plagiarism or any other cheating will be reported to the university leadership, and will have serious consequences. Avoiding any form of plagiarism is in your own interest. If you plagiarize and it is unveiled at a later stage only, it will not only reflect badly on the university, but also on your image/career opportunities.

Plagiarism is academic misconduct, and we take it very serious at ShanghaiTech. In the past we have had lots of problems related to plagiarism especially with newly arriving students, so it is important to get this right upfront:

You may ...

  • ... discuss with your peers about course material.
  • ... discuss generally about the programming language, some features, or abstract lines of code. As long as it is not directly related to any homework, but formulated in a general, abstract way, such discussion is acceptable.
  • ... share test cases with each other.
  • ... help each other with setting up the development environment, etc.

You may not ...

  • ... read, possess, copy or submit the solution code of anyone else (including people outside this course or university)!
  • ... receive direct help from someone else (i.e. a direct communication of some lines of code, no matter if it is visual, verbal, or written)!
  • ... give direct help to someone else. Helping one of your peers by letting him read your code or communicating even just part of the solution in written or in verbal form will have equal consequences.
  • ... gain access to another one‚Äôs account, no matter if with or without permission.
  • ... give your account access to another student. It is your responsibility to keep your account safe, always log out, and choose a safe password. Do not just share access to your computer with other students without prior lock‚Äêout and disabling of automatic login functionality. Do not just leave your computer on without a lock even if it is just for the sake of a 5‚Äêminute break.
  • ... work in teams. You may meet to discuss generally about the material, but any work on the homework is to be done individually and in privacy. Remember, you may not allow anyone to even just read your source code.

With the Internet, "paste", and "share" are easy operations. Don‚Äôt think that it is easy to hide and that we will not find you. We have just as easy to use, fully automatic and intelligent tools that will identify any potential cases of plagiarism. And do not think that being the original author will make any difference. Sharing an original solution with others is just as unethical as using so meone else‚Äôs work.

‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞Âú®Êüê‰∏ÄÁÇπËøûÁª≠ÊòØÊåáÂáΩÊï∞Âú®Êüê‰∏ÄÁÇπÁöÑÊûÅÈôêÂÄºÁ≠â‰∫éËØ•ÁÇπÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÂÄº„ÄÇ

Êõ¥ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂíåÁ¨¶Âè∑Âåñ‰∏Ä‰∫õÔºåÂØπ‰∫é‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y)ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂú®Êüê‰∏™ÁÇπ (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Â§ÑÔºåÂΩì (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) Ë∂ãËøë‰∫é (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Êó∂ÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ÂÄº f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) ‰πüË∂ãËøë‰∫é f(a,b)f(a,b)f(a,b)ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊàë‰ª¨Áß∞Ëøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÁÇπ (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Â§ÑËøûÁª≠„ÄÇÊç¢Âè•ËØùËØ¥ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú lim‚Å°(x,y)‚Üí(a,b)f(x,y)=f(a,b)\lim_{(x,y)\to (a,b)}f(x,y) = f(a,b)lim(x,y)‚Üí(a,b)‚Äãf(x,y)=f(a,b)ÔºåÈÇ£‰πà f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÁÇπ (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Â§ÑËøûÁª≠„ÄÇ

Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÊØè‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩËøûÁª≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Áß∞Ëøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØËøûÁª≠ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

2. Èó¥Êñ≠

‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÈó¥Êñ≠ÂèØ‰ª•ÂàÜ‰∏∫‰∏âÁßçÁ±ªÂûãÔºö

  1. Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁ±ªÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπÔºöÂΩì (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) Ë∂ãËøë‰∫é (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Êó∂ÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊûÅÈôêÂ≠òÂú®Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰∏é f(a,b)f(a,b)f(a,b) ‰∏çÁõ∏Á≠â„ÄÇËøôÁßçÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπ‰πüË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫ÂèØÂéªÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπ„ÄÇ

  2. Á¨¨‰∫åÁ±ªÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπÔºöÂΩì (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) Ë∂ãËøë‰∫é (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Êó∂ÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊûÅÈôê‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®ÊàñËÄÖ‰∏∫Êó†Á©∑Â§ßÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÁÇπÈôÑËøëÈúáËç°‰∏çÂÆöÔºåÊ≤°ÊúâÁ°ÆÂÆöÁöÑÊûÅÈôêÂÄº„ÄÇËøôÁßçÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπ‰πüË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫Ë∑≥Ë∑ÉÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπ„ÄÇ

  3. Á¨¨‰∏âÁ±ªÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπÔºöÂΩì (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) Ë∂ãËøë‰∫é (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Êó∂ÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊûÅÈôêÊó¢‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®ÔºåÂèàÊó†Á©∑Â§ß„ÄÇËøôÁßçÈó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπ‰πüË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫Êó†Á©∑Èó¥Êñ≠ÁÇπ„ÄÇ

ÂΩì‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞Âú®Êüê‰∏™ÁÇπ (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Â§Ñ‰∏çÊª°Ë∂≥ËøûÁª≠ÊÄßÊó∂ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Áß∞ËØ•ÂáΩÊï∞Âú® (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) Â§ÑÂá∫Áé∞‰∫ÜÈó¥Êñ≠ÊàñËÄÖËØ¥ÊòØ‰∏çËøûÁª≠„ÄÇ

3. ËøûÁª≠ÁöÑÊÄßË¥®

‰∏Ä‰∫õÊÄßË¥®ÂèØ‰ª•Â∏ÆÂä©Êàë‰ª¨Âà§Êñ≠‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØÂê¶ËøûÁª≠Ôºö

  1. ‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÊØè‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩËøûÁª≠„ÄÇ

  2. Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏§‰∏™‰∫åÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÈÉΩÂú®Êüê‰∏™ÁÇπËøûÁª≠ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂíå„ÄÅÂ∑Æ„ÄÅÁßØ„ÄÅÂïÜÔºàÂàÜÊØç‰∏ç‰∏∫Èõ∂Ôºâ‰πüÂú®ËØ•ÁÇπËøûÁª≠„ÄÇ

  3. ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§öÈ°πÂºèÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÊòØËøûÁª≠ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

  4. ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúâÁêÜÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÈô§‰∫ÜÂÆÉÁöÑÊûÅÁÇπÂ§ñÈÉΩÊòØËøûÁª≠ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

  5. ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏âËßíÂáΩÊï∞ÊàñËÄÖÊåáÊï∞ÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÈÉΩÊòØËøûÁª≠ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

  6. Â§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑËøûÁª≠ÊÄßÔºöËã• f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú® (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) ËøûÁª≠ÔºåËÄå g(u,v)g(u,v)g(u,v) Âú® (f(a,b),c)(f(a,b),c)(f(a,b),c) ËøûÁª≠ÔºåÂàôÂ§çÂêàÂáΩÊï∞ h(u,v)=g(f(u,v),c)h(u,v) = g(f(u,v), c)h(u,v)=g(f(u,v),c) Âú® (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) ËøûÁª≠„ÄÇ

4. ÂáΩÊï∞ÂÖâÊªë

ÂáΩÊï∞ÂÖâÊªëÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊåáÁöÑÊòØÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÂÖ∑ÊúâËâØÂ•ΩÁöÑËøûÁª≠ÊÄß„ÄÅÂèØÂØºÊÄßÂíåÈ´òÈò∂ÂèØÂØºÊÄß„ÄÇ

‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËØ¥ÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÊó†ÈôêÊ¨°ÂèØÂØºÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÂØºÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖËøûÁª≠ÔºåÊ≤°Êúâ‰ªª‰ΩïÊñ≠ÁÇπÊàñËÄÖËßíÁÇπ[3]„ÄÇ

‰ªéËßÜËßâ‰∏äËØ¥ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂáΩÊï∞Âú®Êüê‰∏™ÁÇπÂ§ÑÂÖâÊªëÔºåÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÁÇπÈôÑËøëÁöÑÂèòÂåñ‰∏ç‰ºöÂá∫Áé∞Á™ÅÁÑ∂ÁöÑÂèòÂåñÊàñËÄÖËßíÂ∫¶ÔºåËÄåÊòØÂëàÁé∞Âá∫‰∏ÄÁßçÂπ≥ÊªëÁöÑÂèòÂåñË∂ãÂäø„ÄÇ

Âú®Êï∞Â≠¶‰∏äÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈÄöÂ∏∏Áî®ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞Êù•ÊèèËø∞ÂÖ∂ÂÖâÊªëÊÄß„ÄÇÂΩìÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÊØè‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÂèØÂØºÊó∂ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Áß∞Ëøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØÂÖâÊªëÁöÑ„ÄÇÁâπÂà´Âú∞ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖÁöÑÂØºÂáΩÊï∞‰πüËøûÁª≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Áß∞Ëøô‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØÂÖâÊªëÂèØÂæÆÁöÑ„ÄÇ

ËøûÁª≠ÂíåÂÖâÊªëÊòØ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞Âú®Êüê‰∏™ÁÇπÂ§ÑËøûÁª≠‰∏ç‰∏ÄÂÆöÂÖâÊªëÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËØ¥‰∏Ä‰∏™ËøûÁª≠ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞Âú®Êüê‰∏™ÁÇπÂ§Ñ‰ªçÁÑ∂ÂèØËÉΩÂ≠òÂú®‰∏çÂèØÂØºÁöÑÁÇπÔºåËÄåÂÖâÊªëÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÆö‰πâÂüüÂÜÖ‰∏ÄÂÆöÊòØËøûÁª≠ÁöÑ[4]

5. ‰∫åÂÖÉËøûÁª≠ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊÄßË¥®

ÊúâÁïåÈó≠Âå∫Èó¥Âå∫Âüü‰∏äÁöÑ‰∫åÂÖÉËøûÁª≠ÂáΩÊï∞‰∏éÈó≠Âå∫Èó¥‰∏äÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂÖÉËøûÁª≠ÂáΩÊï∞ÊúâÁ±ª‰ººÁöÑÊÄßË¥®

  • ÊúâÁïåÊÄßÂÆöÁêÜ

    Â¶ÇÊûúÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÊúâÁïåÈó≠Âå∫Âüü DDD ‰∏äËøûÁª≠ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú® DDD ÂÜÖÂøÖÂÆöÊúâÁïåÔºõÂç≥Â≠òÂú®Â∏∏Êï∞ MMMÔºå‰ΩøÂæó ‚à£f(x,y)‚à£‚â§M|f(x,y)| \leq M‚à£f(x,y)‚à£‚â§M„ÄÇ

  • ÊúÄÂÄºÂÆöÁêÜ

    Â¶ÇÊûúÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÊúâÁïåÈó≠Âå∫Âüü DDD ‰∏äËøûÁª≠ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú® DDD ÂÜÖÂøÖÂÆöÊúâÊúÄÂ§ßÂÄºÂíåÊúÄÂ∞èÂÄºÔºõÂç≥Â≠òÂú® (x0,y0)‚ààD(x_0,y_0) \in D(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)‚ààDÔºå‰ΩøÂæó f(x0,y0)‚â•f(x,y)f(x_0,y_0) \geq f(x,y)f(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)‚â•f(x,y) ÂØπ‰∫éÊâÄÊúâ (x,y)‚ààD(x,y) \in D(x,y)‚ààD ÊàêÁ´ãÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂ≠òÂú® (x1,y1)‚ààD(x_1,y_1) \in D(x1‚Äã,y1‚Äã)‚ààDÔºå‰ΩøÂæó f(x1,y1)‚â§f(x,y)f(x_1,y_1) \leq f(x,y)f(x1‚Äã,y1‚Äã)‚â§f(x,y) ÂØπ‰∫éÊâÄÊúâ (x,y)‚ààD(x,y) \in D(x,y)‚ààD ÊàêÁ´ã„ÄÇ

  • Èõ∂ÁÇπÂ≠òÂú®ÂÆöÁêÜ

    Â¶ÇÊûúÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÊúâÁïåÈó≠Âå∫Âüü DDD ‰∏äËøûÁª≠ÔºåÂπ∂‰∏î f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú® DDD ÁöÑËæπÁïå‰∏ä‰∏çÂèòÂè∑ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú® DDD ÂÜÖÂøÖÂÆöÂ≠òÂú®Ëá≥Â∞ë‰∏Ä‰∏™Èõ∂ÁÇπÔºõÂç≥Â≠òÂú® (x0,y0)‚ààD(x_0,y_0) \in D(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)‚ààDÔºå‰ΩøÂæó f(x0,y0)=0f(x_0,y_0) = 0f(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)=0„ÄÇ

  • ‰ªãÂÄºÂÆöÁêÜ

    Â¶ÇÊûúÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú®ÊúâÁïåÈó≠Âå∫Âüü DDD ‰∏äËøûÁª≠ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂØπ‰∫é‰ªªÊÑè a‚àà[fmin‚Å°,fmax‚Å°]a \in [f_{\min},f_{\max}]a‚àà[fmin‚Äã,fmax‚Äã]ÔºåÈÉΩÂ≠òÂú® (x0,y0)‚ààD(x_0,y_0) \in D(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)‚ààDÔºå‰ΩøÂæó f(x0,y0)=af(x_0,y_0) = af(x0‚Äã,y0‚Äã)=aÔºõÂÖ∂‰∏≠ fmin‚Å°f_{\min}fmin‚Äã Âíå fmax‚Å°f_{\max}fmax‚Äã ÂàÜÂà´ÊòØÂáΩÊï∞ f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) Âú® DDD ‰∏äÁöÑÊúÄÂ∞èÂÄºÂíåÊúÄÂ§ßÂÄº„ÄÇ

  1. 1.ÊåáËá™ÂèòÈáèÊ≤øÁùÄ‰∏ÄÊù°ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑÊõ≤Á∫øÊàñÁõ¥Á∫øË∑ØÂæÑÔºàÂç≥‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂõæÂΩ¢‰∏∫Á∫øÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÔºâÂèòÂåñ„ÄÇ ‚Ü©
  2. 2.ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Âè™ÈúÄË¶ÅËÄÉËôëËá™ÂèòÈáèÊ≤øÁùÄ‰∏ÄÊù°Ë∑ØÂæÑË∂ãËøë‰∫éÊüê‰∏ÄÁÇπ„ÄÇ ‚Ü©
  3. 3.ËßíÁÇπÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÂõæÂÉè‰∏äÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁßçÁâπÊÆäÁÇπÔºå‰πüÁß∞‰∏∫ÊãêÁÇπÔºõÂú®Ëøô‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏äÔºåÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂõæÂÉèÁ™ÅÁÑ∂ÊîπÂèò‰∫ÜÊñπÂêëÔºåÁ±ª‰ºº‰∫é‰∏ÄÊù°Áõ¥Á∫øÁöÑËΩ¨ËßíÂ§Ñ„ÄÇ ‚Ü©
  4. 4.Âõ†‰∏∫Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞ÊòØÂÖâÊªëÁöÑÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂÆÉÁöÑÂØºÊï∞Â≠òÂú®ÔºåËÄåÂØºÊï∞ÁöÑÂ≠òÂú®‰øùËØÅ‰∫ÜÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ËØ•ÁÇπÁöÑËøûÁª≠ÊÄß„ÄÇ ‚Ü©

entry.title: Â§öÂÖÉÂæÆÂàÜÂ≠¶ [1]
entry.content:
ÂØπÂ∫î„ÄäÂ§ßÂ≠¶Êï∞Â≠¶ ÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ ‰∏ã„ÄãÔºö‚Äú8.1 Â§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨Ê¶ÇÂøµ‚Äù

Êú¨ÁØáÂÜÖÂÆπ:

  • Â§öÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÁöÑÁÆÄ‰ªã
  • nnn Áª¥ÁÇπÈõÜ
  • Â§öÂÖÉÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµ

ÁÆÄ‰ªã

ÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÊòØÊï∞Â≠¶‰∏≠‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÂàÜÊîØÔºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÁ†îÁ©∂ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞ÂíåÁßØÂàÜÔºåÂàÜ‰∏∫‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÂíåÂ§öÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ‰∏§‰∏™ÈÉ®ÂàÜ„ÄÇ
ÁÆÄÂçïÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÂ§öÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÁöÑÊé®ÂπøÔºå‰ΩÜ‰πüÊúâÊú¨Ë¥®ÁöÑ‰∏çÂêåÔºö

  • ÂÆö‰πâËåÉÂõ¥‰∏çÂêå
    ‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÊòØÁ†îÁ©∂‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëá™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂØºÊï∞ÂíåÁßØÂàÜÔºåËÄåÂ§öÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÂàôÊòØÁ†îÁ©∂Â§ö‰∏™Ëá™ÂèòÈáèÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂÅèÂØºÊï∞ÂíåÁßØÂàÜ„ÄÇ

  • Á†îÁ©∂ÂØπË±°‰∏çÂêå
    Âú®‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ‰∏≠ÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂ÁöÑÊòØÂÆûÊï∞ÈõÜ‰∏äÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Âè™ÈúÄË¶ÅËÄÉËôë‰∏Ä‰∏™Ëá™ÂèòÈáèÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§ËÆ°ÁÆóÂØπË±°Âè™Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèòÈáè„ÄÇËÄåÂú®Â§öÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ‰∏≠ÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂ÁöÑÊòØÊ¨ßÊ∞èÁ©∫Èó¥‰∏äÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅËÄÉËôëÂ§ö‰∏™Ëá™ÂèòÈáèÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§ËÆ°ÁÆóÂØπË±°Â∞±ÂèòÊàê‰∫ÜÂ§ö‰∏™ÂèòÈáè„ÄÇ

  • ÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÊÄßË¥®‰∏çÂêå
    ‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜ‰∏ªË¶ÅÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÊûÅÈôê„ÄÅËøûÁª≠ÊÄß„ÄÅÂØºÊï∞„ÄÅÁßØÂàÜÁ≠âÊÄßË¥®„ÄÇ
    Â§öÂÖÉÂæÆÁßØÂàÜÈô§‰∫ÜÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑËøô‰∫õÊÄßË¥®Â§ñÔºåËøòÊ∂âÂèäÂà∞ÂêëÈáèÂÄºÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÅÂÅèÂØºÊï∞„ÄÅÊñπÂêëÂØºÊï∞„ÄÅÊ¢ØÂ∫¶„ÄÅÊï£Â∫¶„ÄÅÊóãÂ∫¶„ÄÅÊõ≤Á∫øÁßØÂàÜ„ÄÅÊõ≤Èù¢ÁßØÂàÜÁ≠âÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇ

‰ª•‰∫åÁª¥Âπ≥Èù¢‰∏äÁöÑÁÇπÈõÜ‰∏∫‰æãÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú SSS ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âå∫ÂüüÔºàÊØîÂ¶Ç‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂúÜÔºâÔºåÂàô SSS ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂºÄÈõÜÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂúÜÂÜÖÈÉ®ÁöÑÊØè‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÊòØÂúÜÁöÑÂÜÖÁÇπ„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàë‰ª¨ÊääÂúÜÂë®‰∏äÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÁÇπ‰πüÂåÖÊã¨ËøõÂéªÔºåÈÇ£‰πà SSS Â∞±Êàê‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Èó≠ÈõÜ„ÄÇSSS ÁöÑËæπÁïåÂàôÊòØÂúÜÂë®‰∏äÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÁÇπ„ÄÇÊõ¥‰∏ÄËà¨Âú∞ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•Â∞ÜÂºÄÈõÜ„ÄÅÈó≠ÈõÜÂíåËæπÁïåË°®Á§∫‰∏∫Ôºö

5. ËÅîÈÄöÁöÑÁÇπÈõÜ

‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÈõÜ SSS Ë¢´Áß∞‰∏∫ËÅîÈÄöÁöÑÔºåÂΩì‰∏î‰ªÖÂΩìËØ•ÁÇπÈõÜÂÜÖÁöÑ‰ªªÊÑè‰∏§ÁÇπÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá‰∏ÄÊù°‰Ωç‰∫é SSS ‰∏≠ÁöÑËøûÁª≠Êõ≤Á∫øÁõ∏‰∫íËøûÊé•„ÄÇËøôÈáåÁöÑ‚ÄúËøûÁª≠Êõ≤Á∫ø‚ÄùÂèØ‰ª•ÁÆÄÂçïÂú∞ÁêÜËß£‰∏∫Á∫øÊÆµ„ÄÅÊäòÁ∫ø„ÄÅÊõ≤Á∫øÁ≠âÁ≠âÔºåËÄå‚ÄúÁõ∏‰∫íËøûÊé•‚ÄùÂàôÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÂú®ËøôÊù°Êõ≤Á∫øÁöÑ‰∏§Á´ØÁÇπÂ§ÑÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÁÇπÈõÜ SSS ‰∏≠ÊâæÂà∞‰∏§‰∏™ÁÇπ‰∏éËøô‰∏§‰∏™Á´ØÁÇπÁõ∏ÂØπÂ∫î„ÄÇ

Êõ¥ÂΩ¢ÂºèÂåñÂú∞ËØ¥ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂØπ‰∫é‰ªªÊÑèÁöÑ a,b‚ààSa,b\in Sa,b‚ààSÔºåÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ÊâæÂà∞‰∏ÄÊù°ËøûÁª≠ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∞ Œ≥:[0,1]‚ÜíS\gamma:[0,1]\to SŒ≥:[0,1]‚ÜíSÔºåÊª°Ë∂≥ Œ≥(0)=a\gamma(0) = aŒ≥(0)=a ‰∏î Œ≥(1)=b\gamma(1) = bŒ≥(1)=bÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÁß∞ SSS ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÅîÈÄöÁöÑÁÇπÈõÜ„ÄÇ

ËÅîÈÄöÁöÑÂºÄÈõÜÁß∞‰∏∫ÂºÄÂå∫ÂüüÔºå‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Áõ¥Êé•Áß∞‰ΩúÂå∫ÂüüÔºåÂå∫ÂüüËøûÂêåÂÖ∂ËæπÁïåÁß∞‰∏∫Èó≠Âå∫Âüü„ÄÇ

6. Âü∫Á°ÄÊÄßË¥® ÔºàoptionalÔºâ

  • Èó≠ÂêàÊÄßÔºö

Â¶ÇÊûúÁÇπÈõÜ‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÇπÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•Áî±ËØ•ÁÇπÈõÜ‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖ∂‰ªñÁÇπÈÄöËøáÊüêÁßçÊìç‰ΩúÂæóÂà∞ÔºåÂàôËØ•ÁÇπÈõÜÂÖ∑ÊúâÈó≠ÂêàÊÄß„ÄÇ

MathJax ÂÖ¨Âºè

$ Ë°®Á§∫Ë°åÂÜÖÂÖ¨ÂºèÔºö

Ë¥®ËÉΩÂÆàÊÅíÊñπÁ®ãÂèØ‰ª•Áî®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂæàÁÆÄÊ¥ÅÁöÑÊñπÁ®ãÂºè E=mc2E=mc^2E=mc2 Êù•Ë°®Ëææ„ÄÇ

$$ Ë°®Á§∫Êï¥Ë°åÂÖ¨ÂºèÔºö

‚àëi=1nai=0\sum_{i=1}^n a_i=0i=1‚àën‚Äãai‚Äã=0

f(x1,xx,‚Ä¶,xn)=x12+x22+‚ãØ+xn2f(x_1,x_x,\ldots,x_n) = x_1^2 + x_2^2 + \cdots + x_n^2f(x1‚Äã,xx‚Äã,‚Ä¶,xn‚Äã)=x12‚Äã+x22‚Äã+‚ãØ+xn2‚Äã

ÈîôËØØÁöÑÂÖ¨Âºè‰∏ç‰ºöË¢´Ê∏≤ÊüìÔºö

‚àëk=0j‚àí1Œ≥^kjzk\sum^{j-1}_{k=0}{\widehat{\gamma}_{kj} z_k}k=0‚àëj‚àí1‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äãkj‚Äãzk‚Äã

Ê≠£Á°ÆÁöÑ$$\sum_{k=0}^{j-1}{\widehat{\gamma}_{kj} z_k}$$Êâç‰ºöÔºö

‚àëk=0j‚àí1Œ≥^kjzk\sum_{k=0}^{j-1}{\widehat{\gamma}_{kj} z_k}k=0‚àëj‚àí1‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äãkj‚Äãzk‚Äã

Êõ¥Â§çÊùÇÁöÑÂÖ¨Âºè:

\begin{eqnarray}\vec\nabla \times (\vec\nabla f) & = & 0 \cdots\cdotsÊ¢ØÂ∫¶Âú∫ÂøÖÊòØÊó†ÊóãÂú∫\\\vec\nabla \cdot(\vec\nabla \times \vec F) & = & 0\cdots\cdotsÊóãÂ∫¶Âú∫ÂøÖÊòØÊó†Êï£Âú∫\\\vec\nabla \cdot (\vec\nabla f) & = & {\vec\nabla}^2f\\\vec\nabla \times(\vec\nabla \times \vec F) & = & \vec\nabla(\vec\nabla \cdot \vec F) - {\vec\nabla}^2 \vec F\\\end{eqnarray}

entry.title: Êê≠Âª∫ÂçöÂÆ¢ËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÈÅáÂà∞ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢ò
entry.content:
Âú®ÊàëÊê≠Âª∫ÂçöÂÆ¢ÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÈÅáÂà∞Ëøá‰∏Ä‰∫õÊØîËæÉÊ£òÊâãÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåËøô‰∫õÂÜÖÂÆπ‰ª•10%ÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπÂç†ÊúâÁéáËÄóË¥π‰∫ÜÊàë80%ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ÔºõÁî±‰∫é‰∏™‰∫∫ËÉΩÂäõÁöÑÁºòÊïÖÔºåËß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏ägoogle„ÄÅÁÆÄ‰π¶ÂíåcsdnÊâæ„ÄÇ

Áé∞Âú®ÊàëÂ∞ÜÊàëÈÅáÂà∞ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢òÂíåËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÊäÑÂÜôÂú®ËøôÈáåÔºå‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁªèÈ™åÊÄªÁªì„ÄÇ

TIPS: Â∏¶Êúâ‰∏ãÂàíÁ∫øÁöÑÊòØË∂ÖÈìæÊé•ÔºåÂèØÊâìÂºÄÔºõÊúÄÂ∫ïÁ´ØÊúâËÑöÊ≥®Ê±áÊÄªÔºåÈáåÈù¢‰πüÊúâÂèØÊâìÂºÄÁöÑË∂ÖÈìæÊé•„ÄÇ

ÂÜÖÁΩÆÊí≠ÊîæÂô®

ÁΩëÊòì‰∫ëÂ§ñÈìæÊí≠ÊîæÂô®

ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÊåÇËΩΩËøô‰∏™Êí≠ÊîæÂô®ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁöÑÁÆÄÂçïÔºåÂú®ÁΩëÁªú‰∏äÊïôÁ®ãÈöèÂ§ÑÂèØËßÅÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§ÊàëÂè™Âú®Ê≠§Êèê‰æõÁªÜËäÇ‰∏ä‰∏Ä‰∫õÁöÑtips„ÄÇ

  • ÁΩëÊòì‰∫ëÁöÑÂ§ñÈìæÊí≠ÊîæÂô®ÈÄâÈ°π‰∏≠ÊúâËá™Âä®Êí≠ÊîæÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØËøô‰∏™ÂäüËÉΩÂæàÂÆπÊòìË¢´Áé∞Âú®ÁöÑÊµèËßàÂô®Êã¶Êà™[1]ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Ëá™Âä®Êí≠ÊîæÂ§±Êïà‰∏çÁî®ÊãÖÂøÉÔºåËøôÊòØÊ≠£Â∏∏ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

  • ÁΩëÊòì‰∫ë‰∏≠ÈúÄË¶ÅVIPÁöÑÈü≥‰πêÂè™ËÉΩÊí≠Êîæ30s„ÄÇ

APLAYERÊí≠ÊîæÂô®

Ëøô‰∏™ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÁõ∏ÊØîÁΩëÊòì‰∫ëÊí≠ÊîæÂô®‰ºöÊõ¥Â•Ω‰∫õÔºå‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢ÂÆÉÊîØÊåÅ‰ΩøÁî®metingjs;[2]Âè¶‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢Êí≠ÊîæÂô®ÁöÑÊ†∑Âºè‰ºöÂ•ΩÁúã‰∏Ä‰∫õ Ôºà‰∏™‰∫∫ËßÇÁÇπÔºöÁΩëÊòì‰∫ëÁöÑÊí≠ÊîæÂô®ÁúãÁùÄÊúâ‰∫õÁÆÄÈôãÔºâ„ÄÇ

‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÂú®ÊàëÈÖçÁΩÆÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÂèëÁé∞APLAYERÂÆòÁΩëÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂØπÊàëÁöÑÂçöÂÆ¢ÁΩëÁ´ôÊØ´Êó†‰ΩúÁî®„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ[3]

  1. Âú®ËØ∑Ê±ÇÊèí‰ª∂ÂêéÔºå‰æøÂºÄÂßãÈÖçÁΩÆÊí≠ÊîæÂô®„ÄÇÂ∞ÜÂ¶Ç‰∏ã‰ª£Á†ÅÊîæÂÖ• themes/next/layout/-macro ÁõÆÂΩï‰∏ãÁöÑ sidebar.swig Êñá‰ª∂Êàñ themes/next/layout ÁõÆÂΩï‰∏ãÁöÑ layout.swig Êñá‰ª∂„ÄÇËØ∑Ëá™Ë°åÈòÖËØªÊ∫êÁ†ÅÊù•Á°ÆÂÆö‰Ω†Ë¶ÅÊèíÂÖ•ÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆ[5]Ôºå‰ª£Á†Å‰∏≠ÁöÑÂèÇÊï∞ÈÉΩÊòØÊàëËá™Â∑±ËÆæÂ•ΩÁöÑÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂèÇËÄÉÂÆòÊñπDOCSÊù•Ëá™Ë°åËÆæÁΩÆÔºåmarkdownÁöÑË°®Ê†ºËæìÂÖ•Ëµ∑Êù•ËøòÊØîËæÉÈ∫ªÁÉ¶ÔºåÊàë‰πüÂØº‰∏çÂá∫Âà´‰∫∫Ë°®Ê†ºÁöÑmarkdownÊ∫êÁ†ÅÔºàÂà´ÈóÆÔºåÈóÆÂ∞±ÊòØËèúÔºâ„ÄÇ

ÂÖ®Â±ÄÊí≠Êîæ

ÂΩìËÆæÁΩÆÂ•ΩÊí≠ÊîæÂô®ÂêéÔºåÂæàÂø´‰æøËÉΩÂèëÁé∞Êó†Ê≥ïÂÖ®Â±ÄÊí≠ÊîæÔºåÊØèÂàáÊç¢‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁΩëÈ°µÂ∞±‰ºöËá™Âä®‰∏≠Êñ≠Êí≠ÊîæÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÊâãÂä®ÈáçÊí≠ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Êàë‰ª¨ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÁúüÊ≠£ËÆ©Èü≥‰πêÊí≠ÊîæÂô®ËææÂà∞Â∫îÊúâÁöÑÊïàÊûúÔºåÂ∞±Ë¶ÅÂéªÈÖçÁΩÆÂ•ΩÂÖ®Â±ÄÊí≠ÊîæÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇËØù‰∏çÂ§öËØ¥„ÄÇ

  1. È¶ñÂÖàÁõ¥Êé•Âú®git bash‰∏≠ËΩ¨Âà∞hexoÊ†πÁõÆÂΩï‰∏ãÁöÑnext‰∏ªÈ¢òÁõÆÂΩï‰∏ã
  1. ÂÆâË£ÖpjaxÊ®°Âùó
  1. Âú®Next‰∏ªÈ¢òÁöÑ_config.ymlÊñá‰ª∂‰∏≠ÔºåÂêØÁî®pjaxÊ®°Âùó

Âú®‰∏ÄÁØáblog‰∏≠ÂçïÁã¨ÊèíÂÖ•Èü≥‰πê

ÊúâÊó∂Âè™ÊòØÊÉ≥ÂàÜ‰∫´‰∏ÄÈ¶ñÈü≥‰πêÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊääÂÆÉÊîæÂÖ•Â∑¶‰∏ãËßíÁöÑËÉåÊôØÈü≥‰πêÊí≠ÊîæÂô®ÂæàÈöæËµ∑Âà∞ËâØÂ•ΩÁöÑÂÆâÂà©ÊïàÊûúÔºåËøôÊó∂Êàë‰ª¨Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÂçïÁã¨Ê∞¥Âèë‰∏ÄÁØáblogÊù•‰∏ìÈó®ÂÆâÂà©„ÄÇ

ÊñπÊ≥ï‰∏Ä (Ê≠§ÊñπÊ≥ïÊÅ∞Â•ΩÂú®Ê£ÄÊü•ËøôÁØáblogÊó∂ÂèëÁé∞ÊúâËá¥ÂëΩbugÔºåÊöÇÊó†Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºåÊÖéÁî®)

  1. È¶ñÂÖàÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÂÆâË£ÖÊèí‰ª∂ hexo-tag-aplayer
  1. ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂú®blogÁöÑmarkdownÊñá‰ª∂‰∏≠ÊèíÂÖ•Â¶Ç‰∏ã‰ª£Á†ÅÂú®Â∏åÊúõÂá∫Áé∞Èü≥‰πêÊí≠ÊîæÂô®ÁöÑÂú∞Êñπ„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÂèÇÊï∞Ë∞ÉÊï¥ÂèØ‰ª•ÁßªÊ≠•ÂèÇËÄÉÂÜÖÂÆπ‰∏≠ÁöÑHexo‰∏ªÈ¢òÊèíÂÖ•Èü≥‰πê‰πãaplayerÈü≥‰πêÊí≠ÊîæÂô®

ÊñπÊ≥ï‰∫å (Âà©Áî®Êàë‰ª¨Â∑≤ÁªèÂú®Á∫øÂä†ËΩΩÁöÑaplayerÊèí‰ª∂ÂíåmetingjsÊèíÂÖ•Êí≠ÊîæÂô®)

  • Â∞Ü‰∏ãÂàó‰ª£Á†ÅÊèíÂÖ•markdownÊñá‰ª∂‰∏≠‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•‰∫ÜÔºåÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂèÇÊï∞ÈÖçÁΩÆÂíå‰πãÂâçÁöÑÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÁöÑÔºåËøôÈáåÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆòÊñπDOCSÁöÑ‰º†ÈÄÅÈó®(„ÄÉ'‚ñΩ'„ÄÉ)„ÄÇ

HEXOËÑöÊ≥®

Ê≠£ÊòØÂú®ÂÜôËøôÁØáÂçöÂÆ¢ÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåÊàëÂèëÁé∞markdown‰∏≠ÁöÑËÑöÊ≥®ËØ≠Ê≥ïÊó†Êïà;Ëµ∑ÂàùËøòÊÄÄÁñëÊòØÊàëÈòÖËØªÁöÑmarkdownËØ≠Ê≥ïÊïôÁ®ãËøáÊó∂Ôºå‰∫ãÂÆû‰ºº‰πéÊòØÂõ†‰∏∫hexoÂπ∂‰∏çÂéüÁîüÊîØÊåÅÊ∏≤ÊüìmarkdownÁöÑËÑöÊ≥®ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÈúÄË¶ÅÊàë‰ª¨ÂÆâË£Ö‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑ Reference Êèí‰ª∂ÂÆåÊàêËÑöÊ≥®ÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ

markdownÁöÑËÑöÊ≥®ËØ≠Ê≥ï[6]Âú®ËøôÈáåÂ∞±‰∏çËµòËø∞‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

ËÆæÁΩÆËÉåÊôØÂõæÁâá

Ê≤°ÊÉ≥Âà∞ÂêßÔºå‚ïÆ(‚îÄ‚ñΩ‚îÄ)‚ï≠ ÔºåËÆæÁΩÆËÉåÊôØÂõæÁâáÂ±ÖÁÑ∂Êó†Ê≥ïÂú®nextÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂ÈáåÂÆåÊàêÔºåËÄå‰∏îÁΩë‰∏äÁõõ‰º†ÁöÑÊñ∞Âª∫stlyesÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÊ†πÊú¨Áî®‰∏ç‰∫ÜÔºåÂè™‰ºöÂØºËá¥È°µÈù¢ÊéíÁâàÈîô‰π±„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÁªônext‰∏ªÈ¢òËÆæÁΩÆËÉåÊôØÂõæÁâáÈúÄË¶ÅÊàë‰ª¨Âéª‰øÆÊîπÁõÆÂΩï hemes ext\source\css\_schemes ‰∏ãÁöÑschemeÊñá‰ª∂Â§π‰∏≠ÁöÑ index.html Êñá‰ª∂ÔºàËøôÂèñÂÜ≥‰∫é‰Ω†ÈÄâÊã©ÁöÑschemeÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÊàëÈÄâÊã©‰∫ÜGeminiÔºâ„ÄÇ

  1. ÂáÜÂ§áÂ•Ω‰Ω†ÁöÑËÉåÊôØÂõæÁâá[7]ÔºåÊîæÂú®ÁõÆÂΩï hemes ext\source‰∏ãÁöÑ‰ªªÊÑèÊñá‰ª∂Â§π‰∏≠ÔºàÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÊàëÂª∫ËÆÆÊîæÂú®ÁõÆÂΩï hemes ext\source\images ‰∏ãÔºâ„ÄÇ
